data.title: Jaramillo Creek
data.listingDescription: Fly-fishing stream to test your skills.

images.altText: A shallow creekbed with green grass on both sides. Trees and clouds in the background.
images.title: Jaramillo Creek
images.caption: The smallest creek at Valles Caldera National Preserve

data.bodyText:
Located in the middle of the preserve, Jaramillo Creek is a popular fly fishing area. Although smaller and more overgrown than other streams on the preserve, it provides good fishing for those who enjoy a challenge. Primary species is the non-native brown trout.

There are several elk exclosures to protect willows and other vegetation from browsing elk, but anglers are welcome to fish inside if there is a walk-through or gate. 

Vehicle access to Jaramillo Creek is limited and available seasonally as conditions allow. Access to the creek via hiking, biking, horseback riding, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing is available year-round as conditions allow. Parking is available about 6 miles or 30 minutes from the the Entrance Station. Please obey all speed limits.
data.audioDescription: A shallow and narrow creek bed about a foot wide with green grass growing on both sides in the summer. There are several fence elk exclosures along the stream to protect willows and other vegetation from browsing elk.

data.title: Mica Mining Pit
data.listingDescription: The remains of this mica mining pit, active from the mid 1800's-early 1900's, provides evidence of the Brandywine Valley's industrial history. As an important center for the Industrial Revolution within the United States, the Brandywine Valley provided both raw material and finished products to the nation and abroad, including the mica mined here for use in the production of ceramics.

images.altText: An open pit, approximately 10 feet deep, with gentle sloping sides, surrounded by green woods.
images.title: Mica Mining Pit
images.caption: The Mica Mining Pit above Ramsey Road, in the Brandywine Valley

data.bodyText:
Mica mining started within the Brandywine Valley in the mid 1700's, and from there grew to be one of several major industries present within the Valley. Mica, kaolin, and feldspar were all mined at various locations, with the product then shipped out to ceramic factories in Philadelphia and Wilmington. Feldspar and kaolin were used in the production of porcelain glazes, while mica was used as an insulation agent in the ceramic production process, as well as later on in the production of spark plugs. Usually all three minerals would be mined side by side or within successive waves at the same site. 

This pit in particular was active from approximately 1850-1910. You can still see large amounts of mica flakes spread around the ground surrounding the pit and the remaining spoil piles. It was the production of mica and other minerals from this pit and others like it that served to elevate the Brandywine Valley into one of the first centers of the American industrial revolution. Combined with the mills of various types that dotted the banks of the Brandywine River, this area of northern Delaware was able to position itself as a major producer of both raw materials and finished products.
data.audioDescription: The mica mining pit area is located down a short trail in a heavily wooded area north of Ramsey Road, at the top of a steeply rising hill in the Brandywine Valley. The ground around the pit, out for some distance, is covered in mica flakes, which look like glassy plastic. There are trails surrounding the pit, and it is not unusual to see hikers and bikers using the area. The trees surrounding the pit are mostly tulip poplar and American beech, and the vegetation is very lush and green in the warmer months. The remains of the pit are roughly triangular, with sides measuring approximately 40-50 feet. It is approximately 10 feet deep, with one lip of the pit lower than the other two. There are still remnants of spoil piles visible surrounding the pit. The soil is somewhat sandy and loose when dry.

quickFacts.value: The remains of this mica mining pit, active from the mid 1800's-early 1900's, provides evidence of the Brandywine Valley's industrial history. As an important center for the Industrial Revolution within the United States, the Brandywine Valley provided both raw material and finished products to the nation and abroad, including the mica mined here for use in the production of ceramics.
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Ramsey Overlook
data.listingDescription: This place was nicknamed “The Rocks” by park staff after these large boulders were installed in 2016 to provide a natural bench for visitors to sit and reflect as they take in the rolling hills and winding creeks of the greater Brandywine Valley.

images.altText: Vibrant yellow, orange and red leaves roll along the curves of the hills.
images.title: "The Rocks"
images.caption: Take a moment to reflect on the history of the Brandywine Valley.

data.bodyText:
Park staff placed these large boulders in 2016 to provide a natural bench for visitors to sit and reflect as they take in the rolling hills and scenic vista of the greater Brandywine Valley.

This area was once home to the Lenape village of Queonemysing. As the years passed, English colonists (primarily Quakers) would begin to settle throughout the area. The Quakers took advantage of the fast-moving creeks by building mills that produced wool, paper, and other goods to generate a profit. They also cultivated agricultural fields to support their small village and ship goods up to far destinations. While the mills are no longer visible, you can still see a variety of agricultural fields that have existed for centuries and continue to provide food for the Delaware Valley.   

As you explore more of the Brandywine Valley we ask that you explore safely and practice Leave No Trace principles so this beautiful cultural landscape can remain intact for future generations to enjoy. If you see something suspicious or would like to report trail information (downed tree, etc) please e-mail the park.
data.audioDescription: As you sit on the rocks, you will see rolling forested hills, the winding of the Brandywine Creek and agricultural fields. In the fall, you will see a variety of yellows, oranges, and red leaves that color the skyline.

quickFacts.value: The Brandywine Valley unit preserves more than 1,100 acres of winding rivers and rolling hills that once was home to the Lenape Tribes and early Quaker settlers.
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
data.listingDescription: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch at the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center provide a safe and easy way to launch a kayak to explore Pamlico Sound.

images.altText: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
images.title: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
images.caption: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch

data.bodyText:
The Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch, located at the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center on Bodie Island, provides a great opportunity to put kayaks into the water. Ample parking, loading areas, and maintaned path to Pamlico Sound create an easy access to Pamlico Sound and Oregon Inlet.

Pamlico Sound is an enjoyable place for kayaking, but strong currents and waves can turn a fun visit into a frightening one. Kayaking in the area requires planning and attentiveness- Pamlico Sound and Oregon Inlet serve as a vital artery for fishing boats. Be mindful of vessels, and constantly monitor for their wakes. Always be aware of changing tides and ocean conditions.

The Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch was made possible by support from Outer Banks Forever, Towne Bank, Atlantic Rentals, and Bass Pro Shops.

Kayaking Safely

  • Do not kayak during thunderstorms.
  • Research local hazards and weather, avoid colisions.
  • Bring essential safety gear such as personal floatation devices for everonye onboard, whistle, and a communicaton device.
  • Dress for water immersion, and be aware of hypothermia.
  • Share your plan with a family member or friend.
  • Plan an trip within your capabilities- distances can be deceiving.
data.audioDescription: Enter the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center at the base of the Basnight Bridge, and take an immediate left to the charter boat marina. Stay on the east side of the marina and drive to the end of the pavement. The kayak launch is at the south end of the parking lot.

data.title: Hidden Valley Trail

images.altText: A stream flowing through a small rocky canyon.
images.title: Hidden Valley
images.caption: Hidden Valley along the East Fork of the Jemez River

data.bodyText:
Length: 3.4 miles (5.5 km), out and back round trip
Difficulty: Easy
Elevation: 8406-8573 feet

Trailhead: Locked cable gate at dirt jeep track on the west side of the main entrance road, about ½ mile from the entrance gate.

Parking: Small dirt pull-out adjacent to the trailhead along the main entrance road. Backcountry permit not required.

Route: The trail passes and drops down a small hill to follow the East Fork of the Jemez River as it flows toward the southwestern corner of the preserve, following a narrow valley and passing interesting volcanic formations. Some parts of the trail may be marshy.
data.audioDescription: A small pull off from a dirt road with the trail leading up a grassy hill.

data.title: Northwest Corner Trail

images.altText: An open grassland at the base of forested pine hills.
images.title: Northwest Corner Trail
images.caption: Twin Cabins Canyon along the hike.

data.bodyText:
Length: 9.7 miles (15.6 km) out and back round trip; 12.3 miles (19.8 km) with Extension out and back round trip
Difficulty: Strenuous
Elevation: 8343-9020 feet

Trailhead: Locked cable gate marked VC10 on the north side of the road, about 5.5 miles west of the T-junction.

Parking: Small dirt pull-out adjacent to the trailhead along the backcountry road. If vehicle access to the trailhead is closed due to road conditions and the Extension is required, park at the small dirt pull-out adjacent to the locked cable gate marked VC08 on the south side of the backcountry road, about 4.2 miles west of the T-junction, and hike along the Extension to the trailhead. Vehicle permit required.

Route: The trail climbs steadily but gently northward to a rarely visited corner of the preserve, through shady groves of trees and past idyllic meadows perfect for a secluded picnic or birdwatching.
data.audioDescription: A small dirt pull-out adjacent to the trailhead leading upwards, along the backcountry road.

data.title: San Antonio Mountain Trail

images.altText: The summit of a mountain overlooking a narrow forested valley.
images.title: San Antonio Mountain Trail
images.caption: The view from San Antonio Mountain Trail is rewarding.

data.bodyText:
Length: 11 miles (17.7 km) out and back round trip
Difficulty: Strenuous
Elevation: 8394-9922 feet

Trailhead: Locked cable gate marked VC08 on the south side of the road, about 4.2 miles west of the T-junction.

Parking: Small dirt pull-out adjacent to the trailhead along the road. Vehicle permit required.

Route: The trail heads south from Valle San Antonio, up a narrow drainage, and then steadily climbs as it passes through several beautiful glades before terminating just below the summit of San Antonio Mountain. Good opportunities for wildflowers, especially in spring and fall.
data.audioDescription: A small pull off to a dirt trailhead leading through long, forested glades to a mountain summit.

data.title: Corn Crib
data.listingDescription: This 19th-century structure is one of the oldest buildings in the park. It stored corn that would feed both human and animal residents of the property.

images.altText: Corn Crib with Tobacco Barn behind
images.title: Exterior Image of the Corn Crib
images.caption: The Corn Crib was used to store corn for both human and animal consumption

data.bodyText:
Although the corn crib's design over time has varied greatly, the overall function is like what was first created by the American Indians as a means of storing and drying corn. 

The Corn Crib at Thomas Stone National Historic Site is located on a small hill with only a few other buildings nearby to ensure there is good circulation of air around it. The walls, both interior and exterior, are made of wooden slats to aid in the air flow. 

To deter rats, field mice, and other animals from accessing the corn, the Corn Crib is raised above ground on brick columns that are strategically placed to support the frame. In addition, its elevated height prevents corn from drawing any moisture found in the soil. 

The interior of this Corn Crib has a central passage. This could serve as a workspace, such as for shelling corn. The passage also provided extra air flow for the two narrow chambers at each end of the Corn Crib. 

It is very important that each chamber is small. Corn that is buried too deep is susceptible to rot if there is not enough air flow for it to dry.

quickFacts.value: One of the oldest buildings on the property
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Seminole Rest Wayside, Mounds of Evidence
data.listingDescription: This fifth stop along the Seminole Rest trail presents a wayside interpretive panel that highlights the efforts taken by archeologists during their archeological investigations.

images.altText: Boardwalk path, two visitors stand in front of wayside five.
images.title: Seminole Rest Wayside Five
images.caption: Two visitors read information about the mound.

data.bodyText:
Several mounds exist here at Seminole Rest. Snyder's mound, the largest mound, is not one mass of shells but in some areas seventeen different layers deposited over time. In an effort to find clues to the Timucuans, archeologists are interpreting the layers. 

Clam shells make up most of the mound layers even though other materials, including oysters, conchs, and whelk shells and the remains of sea trout, shark, and bass were discovered. The abundance of clam shells indicates the site was mostly used for harvesting clams. 

There are layers that suggest there were periods when the mound was not used but instead was overgrown with vegetation. Remains of poke berry, hackberry, and skullcap in the layers show vegetation has changed very little over the centuries. Many of these plants may have been used by the Timucua for food, fuel, and medicine.
data.audioDescription: Several mounds exist here at Seminole Rest. Snyder's mound, the largest mound, is not one mass of shells but in some areas seventeen different layers deposited over time. In an effort to find clues to the Timucuans, archeologists are interpreting the layers.  Clam shells make up most of the mound layers even though other materials, including oysters, conchs, and whelk shells and the remains of sea trout, shark, and bass were discovered. The abundance of clam shells indicates the site was mostly used for harvesting clams.  There are layers that suggest there were periods when the mound was not used but instead was overgrown with vegetation. Remains of poke berry, hackberry, and skullcap in the layers show vegetation has changed very little over the centuries. Many of these plants may have been used by the Timucua for food, fuel, and medicine.

data.title: The Tobacco Barn
data.listingDescription: Learn about the importance of the "cash" crop of tobacco for the planters in southern Maryland, including Thomas Stone.

images.altText: Tobacco barn ceiling with drying tobacco hanging from it
images.title: Drying Tobacco
images.caption: Drying tobacco hanging from rafters in the tobacco barn

data.bodyText:
From the 17th to the 19th centuries, Southern Maryland was one of the largest producers of tobacco in North America. Many of the tobacco barns used throughout the area still stand today, evidence of their importance to the area's economy. Most of these barns have been repurposed as houses and outbuildings. 

Most tobacco barns, like the one at Thomas Stone National Historic Site, were large, wide sheds with sloped and shingled roofs. The sides were made of alternating rows of boards or logs that had open slits, allowing air to circulate through the building. A series of beams in the barn's ceiling allowed the tobacco plants to hang upside down from sticks to dry and to "cure" or preserve the tobacco. 

Tobacco farmers in the Chesapeake region would have been forced to light fires in the tobacco barns for the curing process if it were a particularly rainy autumn. Though the heat of the flames assisted in the drying process, it could be dangerous. Thomas Jefferson once noted that "...great care is necessary as it [the tobacco] is very flammable, and it takes fire, the whole, with the house [tobacco barn], consumes as quickly as straw would."

The trick to curing in a tobacco barn was to produce a tobacco leaf neither too dry nor too moist. Excess moisture might cause the tobacco to rot during the shipment across the Atlantic. Leaves that were too dry became brittle and disintegrated before reaching Europe.

Tobacco barns stand today as a tangible reminder that while the crop could bring great wealth to its planters, it could also cause financial ruin if the crop did not survive its transport across the ocean.

data.title: Lukens Lake Trailhead from Tioga Road
data.listingDescription: Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer. This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Please stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy.

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Lukens Lake," and has an icon of a hiker.

data.bodyText:
Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer.

This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Please stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy. The trail is wet and muddy until early August.

Lukens Lake (strenuous)
1.6 miles (2.6 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours,
200 foot (60 m) elevation gain.

Hours
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here
Begin at Lukens Lake Trailhead on Tioga Road, 2 miles east of White Wolf Road

Rules & Regulations
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
data.audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Lukens Lake Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has three green recycle bins, three brown trash bins, two brown food lockers, and one wayside exhibit titled, Upper Montane. The trailhead is across the street and marked by a brown sign with an icon of a hiker inside a white square outline.

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, this is snow country, where plants and wildlife must cope with a high-mountain climate that brings winter snow that can remain until June. Here, the summers are short, cool, and moist. Only specialized species can survive. The red fir is one such hardy tree that can handle snowloads that exceed 30 feet. This tree grows in pure stands in the upper montane zone.

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the bottom to top of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet).

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, The plants and animals of the habitat around you are uniquely connected. Interdependence is the only way to suvive within this extreme environment. One important interrelationship involves fungus, flying squirrels, and owls. Root fungi absorb food from trees, while simultaneously improving the roots' water and nutrient absorption. Truffle-like mushrooms growing from this fungus provide a food source for flying squirrels. In turn, owls prey upon the flying squirrel. In this circle of dependency, one missing link might threaten the survival of all.

Illustration: A tree above ground and its roots below ground are a part of the main focal point of this illustration. A squirrel digs into the soil and reaches an oval-shaped object that is growing on the tree's roots underground. An owl is hovering in the background.

data.title: Mono Pass Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east. This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks. At the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon.

images.altText: A sign that reads, 'Mono Pass,' and has an icon of a hiker and an arrow pointing left, can be seen through some trees.

data.bodyText:
Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east.

This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks. At the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon: from the pass, hike a bit farther toward Upper Sardine Lake.

Mono Pass (moderately strenuous)
8 miles (12.9 km) round-trip; 4-6 hours
1,000 ft (305 m) elevation gain

Parker Pass is also accessible via this trailhead.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here 
Begin at Mono Pass trailhead, on Tioga Road, six miles east of Tuolumne Meadows.

Rules & Regulations 
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
data.audioDescription: The small, paved, parking area for Mono Pass Trailhead is located along the south side of Tioga Road. It is marked by a brown metal sign that has a white icon and text. The sign reads, 'Mono Pass,' and has an icon of a backpacker and an arrow that pointing to the right.In the parking area, there are two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, a row of food lockers, and a small, brown facility, which holds a vault toilet. Two small signs that read, 'no camping,' and 'no dogs,' line the curb, near the trailhead. A wooden fence separates the parking area from the wilderness area.Six signs line the dirt path at the Mono Pass Trailhead. The first sign is a wayside exhibit titled Yosemite Ghost Mines, and has a faded black and white photo of a log structure, too shabby and small to be a cabin, but very cabin-like. Text reads, as early as 1860, prospectors explored Mono Pass in search of rich rock. Here, among the glacially carved granite and craggy peaks of the Sierra crest, these hardy men discovered silver deposits and went to work in hopes of fortune.Buildings of the Past - five log cabins mark the location of the Golden Crown and Ella Bloss miners near Mono Pass. This windswept site was established in 1879 during the Tioga silver boom that also produced Bennettville and the Great Sierra Mine near Tioga Pass. Significant wealth was predicted, but around 1890, the mines were abandoned.A Past Preserved - The cabins are increasingly fragile reminders of mining on the Sierra crest. Please help preserve these valuable historic resources by not using them as campsites or fire shelters. It is illegal to damage, deface, or remove archaeological objects or features from federal land. The second sign is separated into five sections. Two small square panels on top, a large map in the middle, and two small square panels on bottom. The Top left panel is maroon with white text and reads, Mono Pass Trailhead, follow the path of Yosemite's first people, the Miwok, over their trade route to the east.Mono Pass is 3.7 miles and Parker Pass is 5.2 miles. The entire watershed of the Dana Fork of the Tuolumne is closed to overnight camping to protect water quality.The top right panel is blue with white text and reads, Wilderness Regulations, the natural integrity of Yosemite's high country depends on you. Help protect the wilderness, and avoid a citation, by following these regulations.Camp at least four trail miles from all developed areas.Pets, firearms, and bicycles are prohibited in wilderness.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks kills vegetation and causes erosion. Maximum group size for cross-country travel is eight people.Avoid disturbing wildlife and other visitors by keeping quiet on the trail and in camp.Use a gas stove for cooking; wood fires are allowed only below 9,600 feet in existing fire rings using dead and downed wood.Leave campsites as you find them; do not build windbreaks, fire rings, hitch racks, chairs, drainage trenches, or other "improvements."Pack out everything you carry in; do not burn trash.Wilderness permit required for all overnight use.A series of three white circles containing three different icons are outlined in red and have a red diagonal line slashing through the middle. The three icons are of a gun, a dog, and a person on a bicycle.The large middle panel is a detailed map of the eastern portion of the park. Roads, trails, peaks, and lakes are labeled. For more information about Yosemite maps, please call 209/379-1035.The bottom left panel is blue with white text and reads, Water Quality - clean, sparkling water is one of the joys of the high country. Wildlife, wilderness visitors, and people downstream all need clean water to stay healthy.Protect your water suppy by following these regulations and suggestions:Camp at least 100 feet (40 steps) from water.Deposit human waste in a six-inch-deep hole at least 100 feet from water; carry out toilet paper.Wash dishes and yourself at least 100 feet from water; even biodegradable soap pollutes.Carry a large water container and limit your trips to collect water; eroded stream banks and lake shores contribute to poor water quality.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks increases erosion and leads to silt-filled streams.Giardia lamblia is a disease-causing protozoan that can be present in all Sierran water; treat all water before drinking. The bottom right panel is yellow with black text and reads, Black Bears - the health and well-being of Yosemite's bears depends on you.Bears are intelligent, curious, adaptable, and hungry. Human food, however, is harmful to bears and other animals here. Keep wildlife wild by using these food storage methods.At the trailhead: Remove all food, ice chests, and scented items from your car. Store them in food storage lockers where available. Never feed bears or other wildlife.In the backcountry: Store food, garbage, and scented items in bearproof canisters, available at front country locations. Keep items s

data.title: Pothole Dome Meadow
data.listingDescription: Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows. Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome, an approachable hiking route that accesses the top of the dome along with its unobstructed, exciting panoramic views.

images.altText: Several people stand on top of a granite dome which gives views of a large, open meadow surrounded by pine trees. Granite peaks rise above the treeline.

data.bodyText:
Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows.

Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome, an approachable hiking route that accesses the top of the dome along with its unobstructed, exciting panoramic views.

Hours 
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here 
Located along Tioga Road, a mile west of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

Rules & Regulations 
Pets, bicycles, and strollers are not permitted on dirt trails.
Stay on the designated trail. Do not venture out into the meadow, which causes trampling and damages the ecosystem, which is important to the many plants and animals that thrive in this fragile environment.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
data.audioDescription: A roadside turnout with limited parking on the north side of Tioga Road hosts views of a large open meadow and surrounding peaks and domes. A trail to the west of the parking area leads around the outskirts of the meadow, to Pothole Dome, a smooth granite dome that would allow for a slightly higher panoramic view. In the distance, a forest lines the perimeter of the meadow and pointed peaks rise above the tree line. Several signs are posted at the parking area and the start of the path. The first sign in the parking area is a brown sign, outlined in white, and has white text that reads, no camping or overnight parking.The second sign is a small, white, metal sign on a wooden post located on the meadow side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the dirt parking from the meadow. A photo on the upper right side of the sign shows several bright, tall, wildflowers in a lush green meadow with a snow covered peak rising above the pine treeline in the distance. The sign reads, meadow restoration in progress. Trails that pass through sensitive habitats, such as Tuolumne Meadows, can have an impact that reaches far beyond the trail. We are currently working to restore this area. Please stay on the main trail shown in blue on the map. Please stay on designated trail.Photo: Two people walk off-trail through a large meadow. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a dense forest. Map: In a square frame, the Tioga Road is indicated by a blue and white tick line that leads from the upper left corner to the bottom right corner. Above that line, sandwiched between the road and a large white area that indicates the granite of Pothole dome is a meadow, a wetland area represented by an upward-turned, banana shape filled with blue marks. A yellow star and text that reads, "you are here," along with an icon of a hiker inside a red square, which is a trailhead, are along the Tioga Road, one quarter of the way from the top. A blue solid line, which is the Pothole Dome Trail, makes its way around the left side of the banana-shaped wetland area then leads to the right, all the way to the right side of the frame. A red, solid line cuts through the meadow from Tioga Road to Pothole Dome and forks out into two paths, they are marked closed.A wayside exhibit titled Sub-Alpine Zone, is located on the parking side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the meadow from the dirt parking area. Text on the left side of the panel reads, the plants and animals in this zone sometimes have only two and a half months to complete a year's work. At this elevation, the snow can be on the ground well into June, only to return as early as September. Bevause this sub-alpine meadow ecosystem is so fragile, even one person crossing it can cause serious damage - especially if it is wet. By following the trail to your left on your hike to Pothole Dome, you can protect plants and animals during their active season.Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of both labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. At the start of the Pothole Dome Trail, a brown sign outlined in white has white text that reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. data.title: Tioga Road - Cones and Needles Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands beneath a tall tree.

data.bodyText: Have you ever wondered how to tell a fir from a pine? Or why you don't really see rattle snakes or giant sequoias at 9,000 feet elevation? Learn more about red firs and Yosemite's life zones and micro-climate at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This paved roadside turnout is on the west side of Tioga Road and has five wayside exhibits. The area is surrounded by different pine and fir trees and has an open view looking westward.

The first wayside exhibit is titled, Cones and Needles. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, Because of its wide range of elevations, Yosemite encompasses several life zones determined by elevation, moisture, temperature, and exposure to storms. Sometimes, conditions vary significantly within a zone and allow for a micro-climate, a place where the climate contrasts with that of the entire zone. You are in one such micro-climate. Around you, trees that typically grow at higher or lower elevations live in close proximity. Stroll around this area and discover stories of four common Yosemite trees, their relationships with wildlife, and struggles to survive. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, cache crop - ever forget where you left your keys? Chipmunks, ground squirrels, and many birds have the same problem. They bury small caches of seeds here and there, and then forget where they put many of these food caches. Consequently, forgetful birds and animals planted many of the trees nearby. 

A series of four photos show different types of trees. 

Photo one is a Red Fir forest, shown with their long branches drooping from the weight of snow that covers them. The trees are tall with pointed tips and reddish bark. 

Photo two is a single Lodgepole Pine, which has a conical shape that tapers, and grey bark. 

Photo three is a single Jeffrey Pine, which has several large branches shooting off a rather bare trunk. Smaller secondary pine branches shoot off the large primary branches. There is no conical shape to this tree, it is randomly fanned out in all directions. 

Photo four is a single Western White Pine, which is a tall, very narrow, slender conical shape, with branches that are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers.

The second wayside exhibit is titled, Red Fir, abies magnifica, and has a close-up photo of Red Fir bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is reddis-brown and has deep striations. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the red fir is a spectacular tree, impressive for its height and girth. It can sometimes rise above 200 feet tall, and be nearly 10 feet in diameter. The bark of mature trees is deeply furrowed with a distinctive reddish hue. 

Illustration: A brown pine branch shows green needles that are rounded off at the ends, growing directly out of the branch. A rounded pine cone, which has layers upon layers that closely overlap each other, appears to be closed and smooth. Cone size is 9 inches (23 cm).

Caption: Tree ID hint - How can you tell a fir from a pine? Think "F" for friendly fir. The needles of a fir are soft, and they grow from the branch instead of in bunches. 

When Lightning Strikes - Lightning often hits the tallest of these red firs, leaving snag-topped crowns. These damaged areas provide fertile foraging areas for woodpeckers and sapsuckers looking for grubs. The snags also provide homes for nesting owls and squirrels. 

Illustration: A speckled owl with horn-like pointy ears sits on a snaggled tree trunk that seems to have snapped apart.

The third wayside exhibit is titled, Western White Pine, pinus monticola, and has a close-up photo of Western White Pine bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is brown and looks like square plates or bricks that are stacked vertically. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, look beyond the red fir log in front of you. The tree with square-like plates on its bark is the Western White Pine. Their trunks are usually straight, and typically their branches are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers. They cannot tolerate deep shade and generally grow in open spaces where they can soak up the rays of the sun. The Western White Pine is a hardy tree, thriving under conditions produced by ground fires that create the ide

data.title: Tioga Road - Disappearing Meadows Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A stream snakes through a meadow. Pebbles, rocks, and boulders line the bottom and outskirts of the shallow stream. Two mountain peaks rise up above treeline.

data.bodyText: How and why do we seem to be losing our meadows to trees? Is that a good thing? And, are you in the midst of an ancient volcanic mountain range? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
A small, paved, roadside turnout on the south side of Tioga Road has an open view of the area's iconic peaks through meadows with flowing streams. There are also two wayside exhibits and three portable restrooms, one of which is designated accessible. 

On the west side of the driveway, an open meadow that has large boulders scattered about, transitions into a dense pine forest. A wayside exhibit titled, Disappearing Meadow, sits at the edge of the meadow and paved driveway. Text on the left side of the panel reads, as recently as the 1960s, this area was an open wet meadow that dominated the foreground in this view of the Cathedral Range Mountains. However, the meadows are beginning to dry up, providing better conditions for trees to grow. Current science is documenting the increase in Earth's temperature which is advantageous for trees due to longer, warmer growing seasons. While scientists are still investigating other possible reasons for the changes you see, climate change is likely a primary factor. 

Photo: An open meadow has small saplings growing throughout it. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a line of mature, tall trees. 

Caption: 1963 view of Cathedral Range from this meadow. 

Photo: A small grassy area has a dense stand of pine trees.

Caption: In 2009, young trees dominate the same view. 

Black and white photo: a man, dressed in a long sleeved shirt, long pants, and cap, stands among hundreds of sheep bunched together in a meadow, with tall trees surrounding the open pasture.

Caption: In the late 1800s, cattle ranchers and sheep herders drove their herds into these lush grassy meadows to graze. Human occupation and use increased to accommodate the silver mines established in the Tioga area during the 1870s. These human impacts to vegetation and hydrology may accentuate the effects of climate change. 

On the east side of the driveway, a stream snakes through an open meadow that also transitions into a dense forest. A reddish peak rises on the left while a grey, granite peak rises to the right. A wooden sign by the stream reads, domestic water supply - do not contaminate. A wayside exhibit is also stationed here titled, The Core of Volcanoes. Text on the left side of the panel reads, rising before you are two of the highest peaks in Yosemite, Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs. Their reddish-brown color hints at a different origin than the white granites of the other mountains in the park. The metamorphic rocks forming the summit areas of Mounts Dana and Gibbs are the exposed core of an ancient volcanic mountain range that once graced the Pacific coast. Once miles beneath tall volcanoes, they were slowly revealed as erosion stripped away the overlying rocks. 

Photo: Two peaks rise above a treeline. The silhouette of the two mountain peaks that are labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, is outlined with a red dotted line.

Illustration: The cross-section illustration of the inner and outer workings of a volcano are shown, below and above ground. In the ground, a layer of reddish-orange, oval-like chambers of magma lay horizontally, overlapping and connecting to each other. Thick vein-like paths of magma extend upward through a layer of earth, connecting with the layer of oval chambers above. A small portion of the upper part of the reddish-orange oval chambers is white and is labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, and is noted as crystallizing granite. Above the chambers is a brown area, labeled as metamorphic rock, that slopes up into a peak. A red, thin, vein-like line leads from the magma chambers to the peak and exits as a plume of smoke. Other peaks are in the background.

Caption: Magma, or lava, that erupted at the surface created the reddish-brown metamorphic rock of the volcanoes core. Magma that cooled deep beneath the surface crystalized and formed the white granite of the other peaks and domes you see here.

data.title: Tioga Road - Form Follows Fracture Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands at a scenic roadside pullout that overlooks the high country landscape.

data.bodyText: As you drive along the Tioga Road you may notice the granite bedrock is riddled with fractures. You may even see trees taking root in the granite bedrock! How is that possible? Learn more about it at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives an open view looking west. The granite bedrock extends for miles, with boulders strewn about, and trees growing out of fractures in the rock. A wayside exhibit titled, Form Follows Fracture, is near the parking area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the granite bedrock of the Sierra Nevada is riddled with fractures. Major fracture zones dictate where water flows and thus where trees and plants grow. Water in the cracks decomposes the rock and forms soil, creating the conditions for life to grow in this harsh environment. 

Two photos: One photo shows a large mature tree growing out of a granite slab. The second photo shows a one-foot tall sapling growing out of a granite fracture.

Caption: Only the hardiest vegetation is able to grow in this rocky terrain. The Jeffrey pine to your left has two roots growing straight out on either side like a gymnast stretched along a balance beam. 

Photo: An aerial view of a portion of the surrounding terrain, framed in a square, show a squiggly grey line across the top of the square from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." The rest of the square is covered with tree canopies, that look like splotchy dark spots, and a web of lines that crisscross each other. A heavy diagonal line that extends downward and slightly to the left from the red dot is labeled Yosemite Creek. 

Caption: This aerial view of the Yosemite Creek drainage shows that the granite is fractured into a network of cracks, or joints, trending in relatively straight lines. These joints result from tectonic stresses associated with uplift of the Sierra Nevada. Linear joints such as these dictate where the major streams flow, and also control the general shape of the landscape.

data.title: Tioga Road - Glacial Moraine Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands next to a small hillside scattered with different sized boulders.

data.bodyText: Get a personal glimpse of a glacial moraine and learn how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons, at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives a view of a hill strewn with many different-sized granite boulders, on both sides of the Tioga Road. A wayside exhibit titled, Glacial Moraine, is near the turnout area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, The hill in front of you is a clue to how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons. Look over your left shoulder, where the road cuts through the hill. Unlike water-deposited debris, which is layered and sorted by size, this hill is made up of a jumbled mix of sand, gravel, and boulders. Geologists call this deposit a glacial moraine. Material eroded and transported by the Snow Creek Glacier was left here as the glacier receded. Imagine the power it took to move this much earth. 

Photo: A hill along a roadside is covered with many different-sized granite boulders. A red dotted line outlines the entire hill. Many trees grow out from the top of the hill. 

Caption: Where the road cuts through the moraine, you can see the debris left behind by the glacier. 

Illustration: An ice-covered mountainous terrain is shown in a square frame. A few of the peaks popping up over the icefield are Mount Conness in the upper left corner, Mount Dana in the upper right corner, Mount Hoffman, which is midway down and left of center, and Cathedral Peak, which is one-third of the way down and right of center. The majority of the terrain is white, representing the Tuolumne Ice Field, which travels downward and splits into the Tenaya Glacier on the right and the Snow Creek Glacier on the left. Just to the left of the Snow Creek Glacier, near the bottom of the illustration, a red dot indicates, 'you are under here,' and a dotted line represents Tioga Road. 

Caption: Twenty thousand years ago a vast ice sheet covered most of the Tuolumne Meadows area. This ice sheet fed glaciers that flowed east toward Mono Lake, west toward Hetch Hetchy, and southwest toward Yosemite Valley. One of these glaciers, the Snow Creek Glacier, left behind the moraine you see here.

data.title: Tioga Road - High Sierra Stories Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A meadow surrounds a small lake. A few mountain peaks rise up above the nearby treeline.

data.bodyText: How do plants and animals survive at the highest elevations in the park? And, how did people travel in this area from hundreds of years ago to today? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This paved parking area allows open views of the high country. A large, open meadow surrounds the parking area. A pond reflects the reddish-brown mountains that are Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, which rise up over the treeline to the left. To the right, grey granite peaks rise over the treeline in the distance. Large granite boulders are scattered here and there across the flat, open meadow. In the parking lot, a brown sign with a white outline and text reads, no camping or overnight parking. 

The meadow area is roped off from the parking area and two small signs are bolted to knee-height wooden posts. The first sign reads, give plants a chance! Please stay off. An illustration of a foot hovering over small plants is inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through its center. The second sign reads, area closed - restoration in progress, Yosemite National Park, and has a silhouette of Half Dome.

Three wayside exhibits line the curb of the parking lot. The first wayside exhibit, located to the far right of the parking area, is titled, Alpine Zone, and has a faint background photo of a large, smooth, granite peak. Text on the left side of the panel reads, you are now near the alpine zone, which includes the highest elevations in Yosemite. Look a few hundred feet higher, and you can see that trees cannot grow because the rugged terrain is windy, dry, and intensely sunlit. To survive such harsh conditions, plants here lie flat against the ground or crouch between stones. Special pigments in their leaves filter out harmful rays of sunlight. Some plants grow in little pincushion-like bunches. If they stand too tall the wind will dry them out or tear them apart. Their vibrant blossoms burst forth in an extra effort to attract insects. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the far right of the road is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Two photos show two different kinds of wild flowers. The first wildflower is called Davidson's penstemon and is light purple. They are growing in a bunch, out of a crack in a granite rock and are short in stature. Their small flowers are a bit long and flute-like, curving outward at the ends. The second photo shows a wildflower called Sky Pilot, which is purple, and has a spherical bulb of multiple flowers that shoot out of an erect stem. They are growing in a bunch in a rocky area. 

Text on the right side of the panel reads, pikas need to get out of the sun periodically to cool down or they risk lethal overheating. These small mammals live in rock piles at high elevations. They gather plants for winter food in nearby areas, frequently returning to the shade of the rocks. As Earth's temperature warms, they will have to spend more time in the rock piles cooling down. If they have to spend too much time cooling down, they won't be able to harvest enough food to survive the winter. 

Photo: In the bottom right corner, a small, greyish-brown, furry pika faces left and is leaning forward on a rock. It has black beady eyes, large round ears, and long whiskers. 

The second wayside exhibit, located near the middle of the parking area, is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick.

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads

data.title: Tioga Road - Meadow Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a roadside pullout.

data.bodyText: Learn more about the old Mono Trail, a part of a network for American Indian Trade, about the importance of Yosemite's and the Sierra Nevada snow pack, and the history of the Tioga Road, from these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This arched driveway on the south side of Tioga Road has limited, undefined, parking. A green recycle dumpster and brown trash dumpster are located at the east end of the parking area. Trees surround the lot.

Two wayside exhibits stand side by side on the north side of the parking area. The right wayside exhibit is titled Mutual Survival, and has a background photo of a map of central California. Three recognizable areas are labeled, Lake Tahoe, at the top, middle of the panel, San Francisco Bay Area at the left, middle of the panel, and Mono Lake, toward the right middle of the panel. Two large, faint arrows are positioned in a circular way, signifying a counter-clockwise rotation, on the right side of the panel. In the midst of the circular arrows is a map of Yosemite National Park. Panel text reads, Mutual Survival - the Tioga Road follows roughly the same route as the old Mono Trail. This old trail formed the basis of a network for American Indian trade routes leading from the sea to the desert. People on either side of the mountains used this route to negotiate and trade for food items and other materials important to their daily lives. 
Photo Near the San Francisco Bay Area: A string of beads lay on a pink stone, in the sand, next to a seashell.

Caption: Trades from the west bartered with shells and jewelry. 

Photo in the middle of the Central California map: Many acorns are piled up in a basket, and a heap of long sedges is bundled together, laying on its side.

Caption: People in the mountain valleys traded acorns and basket-making materials.

Photo to the upper right of Yosemite National Park: A zoomed-in photo of white granules of salt, and little shrimp swimming bunched together in water. 

Caption: Salt and alkali fly pupa were trade items from the Mono Lake area. 

Illustration to the right of Yosemite National Park and Mono Lake: A black rock with shiny, white edges is shown. 

Caption: Obsidian to make spear and arrow points, knives, and scrapers came from the east. 

The left wayside exhibit is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick. 

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest. 

Caption: By the 1890s, horse-drawn wagons followed Indian migration routes. 

Photo: two women stand on a dirt road, next to a soft-top automobile that has two spare tires attached to the rear. 

Caption: Travelers needed spare tires and plenty of gas in the 1920s. 

Photo: Two vintage cars drive side-by-side, taking up the width of the narrow dirt road, while an oncoming car approaches. A large boulder and plenty of trees are right along the roadside. 

Caption: Motorists in the 1940s traveled slowly, navigating a narrow and treacherous dirt road. 

Photo: A bicyclist wearing a helmet rides on a paved road with snowcapped mountains in the background. 

Caption: In 2009, cyclists enjoy a high country biking experience. 

Photo: An older man with a white beard and mustache, a white long-sleeved shirt and black vest, long pants, and a hat, sits horseback, facing to the left. Caption: "...I have crossed the Range of Light, surely the brightest and best of all the Lord has build; and rejoicing in its glory. I gladly, gratefully, hopefully pray I may see it again." - John Muir

The third wayside exhibit is facing the small meadow on the south side of the parking area and is titled, Shrinking Reservoir. The exhibit panel's background photo shows a snow-covered mountain range in the background, and a few building and utility poles on flat terrain in the foreground. Panel text reads, Shrinking Reservoir - The Sierra Nevada is California's reservoir - nature's storage tank of water in the form of winter snow and ice. As the snow gradually melts, it releases the stored water into streams and rivers. The depth of the annual snow pack indicates how much water we will have each year for necessities like drinking water and crop irrigation. In a changing climate, more moisture may come as rain instead of snow. How will it

data.title: Tioga Road - Surviving the Crossing Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands near a roadside pullout.

data.bodyText: Who were the first non-Indians to pass through this area, and how did they survive? Learn more from this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A small roadside turnout along the south side of Tioga Road allows for scenic views across the street. A clearing in the trees opens up to panoramic views of rolling hills, looking northward. A wayside exhibit titled, Surviving the Crossing, is on the north side of the parking lot.

The background illustration of the panel shows two men manuevering through a dense forest on horseback. Text reads, in 1833, in a trip that took more than two weeks, Joseph R. Walker led a party of mountain men along a ridge near here. They were the first non-Indians to pass through this area as they crossed the Sierra Nevada. Near starvation they finally found an Indian trail that eventually led them to safety, but not before 24 of their horses succumbed - most of which they had to eat for their own survival. 

Quote: We were then obliged to keep along the top of the dividing ridge between two of these chasms which seemed to lead pretty near in the direction we were going...

...A small deer was the first we had eat since our dried meat was exhausted, during which time we lived on stale and forbidden horse flesh...

-Zenas Leonard, Walker Party

data.title: Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley. John Muir once described Ten Lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest."

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Yosemite Creek, Ten Lakes," and has an icon of a hiker.

data.bodyText:
Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley.

Ten Lakes Trailhead
John Muir once described these lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest." To see the lakes, follow this trail through conifers and across granite to cross a tributary of Yosemite Creek. Take care on this crossing early in the season when the creek is high. Continue on the trail to Ten Lakes Pass, overlooking the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne and the Sierra Crest. Then descend 693 feet (211 m) into the Ten Lakes Basin, which contains a series of beautiful High Sierra lakes.

Yosemite Creek Trailhead
This is a beautiful path that mostly follows Yosemite Creek to the rim of the Valley and Yosemite Falls. This trail drops about 2.6 miles through lodgepole pine stands before joining the trail from the Yosemite Creek Campground. The trail continues to parallel Yosemite Creek for another 3.3 miles before intersecting with the Yosemite Falls Trail which originates in Yosemite Valley, 3.5 miles below. Follow the signs to the overlook at Yosemite Point, a short distance to the east, for a glimpse of the breathtaking drop into Yosemite Valley and across the High Sierra. Use caution, wet rocks can be slippery.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a visitor center or information station.

Ten Lakes (strenuous)
12.6 mi (20.3 km) round-trip; 6-8 hours
2,200 ft (671 m) elevation gain

Yosemite Creek (strenuous)
16 miles (25.7 km) round-trip; 8-10 hours

Hours 
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here 
Dependent on which hike, begin at either the Ten Lakes Trailhead or Yosemite Creek Trailhead, which are across the street from each other, along Tioga Road, east of White Wolf Road

Rules & Regulations 
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility
This trail is not accessible.
data.audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, four brown food lockers, a facility holding two vault toilets, one wayside exhibit and one map. Trees and granite bedrock surround the area. A dirt lot is located across the street, which is also where the trailhead for Ten Lakes is located. The trailhead for Yosemite Creek is at the north end of the parking area, marked by a metal sign that reads Yosemite Creek Trail and has an arrow pointing forward.

The wayside exhibit shows a faded, black and white, close-up, background photo of a full waterfall. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, rocks, ice, and water - standing here near Yosemite Creek, one feels only a hint of the power that this busy but unassuming waterway will possess by the time it reaches the floor of Yosemite Valley.

The rocky Yosemite Creek watershed, which slopes downhill to the rim of Yosemite Valley about eight miles away, encompasses some fifty square miles of Yosemite's high country. Carved by tributary glaciers about 20,000 years ago, the V-shaped Yosemite Creek drainage was enlarged by the heavy volume of water and `ice which rushed through as the glacier retreated. Today, as spring snow melts, an average of 2,400 gallons per second of icy runoff is funneled through this hanging valley before plunging over the vertical cliff 2,425 feet to Yosemite Valley below.

Photo: A river with white water flows toward a precipice. Granite bedrock and trees are along the banks. A rock formation blanketed in snow is at the far end of the river.

Caption: Yosemite Creek plunging over the top of Yosemite Falls.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, Yosemite Creek Trail, for hiking and trail information, please visit a Visitor Center or Information Station. This strenuous 16-mile out-and-back trail drops about 2.6 miles through lodgepole pine stands before joining the trail from the Yosemite Creek Campground. The trial continues to parallel Yosemite Creek for another 3.3 miles below. Follow the signs to the overlook at Yosemite Point, a short distance to the east, for a glimpse of the breathtaking drop into Yosemite Valley and across the High Sierra. Use caution, wet rocks can be slippery.

Map: A tall, rectangular map of the surrounding area, shows a horizontal, squiggly, grey line near the top of the map, crossing from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." A dotted diagonal line extends downard and slightly to the left from the red dot, representing the Yosemite Creek Trail. Along the trail, Yosemite Creek Campground and the top of Yosemite Falls are labeled. At the bottom of the dotted line is Yosemite Valley. Upper Yosemite Fall and Lower Yosemite Fall are represented by a series of three blue lines stacked on top of one another, each line shorter than the one above it. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

Photo: A black and white aerial photo shows a three tier waterfall coming over a large rock wall. The upper fall is the longest of the three, the middle cascade the shortest. The lower fall is half the height of the upper fall.

Caption: V-shaped Yosemite Creek watershed and Yosemite Falls.

A map labeled, The Tioga Road, is on a sign board inside a wooden frame. The map shows the entire park with emphasis only on the Tioga Road, which is a red, solid, squiggly line that crosses the map from left to right, midway down the map. Major areas, beginning from the left include Crane Flat, which has icons indicating restrooms, groceries, gas, campground, and two sequioa groves that are in the area. A bit to the right is Tamarack Flat Campground. A quarter of the way across the map is White Wolf, which has icons indicating a campground, dining, and hiking are in that area. About one-third of the way across the map is Yosemite Creek, which has a red dot and text that reads, "you are here." This area is labeled with Hiking, restrooms, and picnic icons. Halfway across the map are Olmsted Point, which has no services, and Tenaya Lake, which has multiple hiking, picnic, and restroom icons in the area. About two-thirds of the way across the map is Tuolumne Meadows, which has icons indicating camping, dining, restrooms, groceries, a wilderness center, and hiking, which includes Cathedral Lakes and Lembert Dome. Near the right side of the map, past Tuolumne Meadows, Mono Pass, a hiking destination, and Tioga Pass, the east entrance and exit to the park, are found along Tioga Road. The road then continues down to the first town outside the park, Lee Vining. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

data.title: The Roosevelt Home Garden
data.listingDescription: The Home Garden, nearly two acres in size, was a central part of life for the Roosevelt family. FDR grew up playing in the garden and savoring its bounty. His children and grandchildren helped work the garden, pulling weeds and harvesting its fruits and vegetables. FDR's memories of the garden helped shape his values and sense of identity.

images.altText: Two boys stand near a cart hold produce from a garden.
images.title: Roosevelt Boys with Garden Produce
images.caption: Franklin Jr and John Roosevelt Proudly Display Produce from the Home Garden

relatedParks.fullName: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt

tags: Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area
data.bodyText:
The Home Garden, nearly two acres in size, was a central part of life for the Roosevelt family. FDR grew up playing in the garden and savoring its bounty. His children and grandchildren helped work the garden, pulling weeds and harvesting its fruits and vegetables. FDR's memories of the garden helped shape his values and sense of identity.

Large home gardens like the Roosevelt's garden were typical features of the diverse, self-sustaining Hudson River estate farms. These farms grew a variety of crops in gardens, fields and orchards and maintained livestock like chickens, hogs and cattle to provide meat as well as eggs and dairy products for the table.

When the Roosevelts originally bought this property, the vegetable garden occupied a small bed in the present-day rose garden and gravesite. Although they were only a family of three, the garden expanded continuously throughout their time at Springwood, even after FDR’s departure for school and James Roosevelt’s death in 1900.

The Home Garden was an integral part of Roosevelt family life. Frequently mentioned in letters between the Roosevelts, it was clearly important not only as a source of food, but as a part of their home—a part they made an effort to enjoy no matter where they were staying. When the Roosevelts weren’t living at Springwood, they would have produce shipped from their garden to wherever they were—to their property in Campobello, to New York, and to FDR at school in Massachusetts.

The current vegetable garden is designed to replicate the Roosevelts’ garden with as much historic accuracy as possible. Minor adjustments are introduced to ensure its health and accessibility, including deer fencing around its perimeter and porous pavement paths. In addition, although the heirloom vegetable varieties grown in the garden today remain the same as during the Roosevelts’ time, they are cultivated using modern organic practices. Bug traps, black biodegradable film, white row cover, and kaolin clay are all examples of these modern strategies used in combat typical garden pests.

The Home Garden is maintained through the support of volunteers who help plant, maintain, and harvest the crops. Produce is donated by the park's philanthropic partner, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Hyde Park Foundation, to Dutchess Outreach in the city of Poughkeepsie. In addition to being a food resource, this garden is used for a variety of educational programs, and is free and open for the public to enjoy. Visit our volunteer page for more information about how you can participate.
data.audioDescription: A large square garden divided by a central path into four quadrants.

quickFacts.value: Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt, 32nd President of the United States
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: The Stone Family Cemetery
data.listingDescription: Thomas Stone and his wife, Margaret Brown Stone, are buried here along with several other members of the Stone and Brown families. Archeological evidence suggests there may be burial shafts outside of the fence.

images.altText: Stone family cemetery
images.title: Stone Family Cemetery
images.caption: Stone Family Cemetery

data.bodyText:
One of the most prominent features of the landscape at Thomas Stone National Historic Site is the Stone Family Cemetery. The cemetery has nine burials inside its fenced-in area. The earliest burials date to 1787, when Margaret and Thomas Stone died within four months of each other. The last burial occurred in 1913, when one of the last Stone owners of the property, Margaret Graham Stone, died. Six other markers of extended Stone family members who died between 1841-1873, including two children, are also there.

Outside of the fenced-in area, arranged in a rectangular pattern are four small stone markers. Oral tradition states that the stones mark a separate cemetery, a cemetery comprised of the enslaved who died in bondage and were buried next to the family cemetery. When the Stones sold the property in 1936, they put a stipulation in the sales contract that permitted one future burial, that of a former enslaved person, in the area outside the fence, but no burials inside. A Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) study done here shows evidence of 19 burial shafts in this area but does not indicate how many people are actually buried in this location, nor if they were burials of enslaved persons.

This theory is problematic, however. In the Chesapeake region, enslaved people were rarely laid to rest near those who claimed ownership over them. It was more common for the enslaved to have their own burial grounds near their quarters or in undeveloped ground close by.

Do these four stones outline an enslaved cemetery, or an extended cemetery for other Stone family members who did not reside here? More research needs to be conducted before the answers can be revealed.

data.title: Seminole Rest Wayside, The Timucuan Way of Life

images.altText: Wayside on on the sidewalk with a Jacque LeMoyne painting of Timucua attempting to catch a gator.
images.title: Seminole Rest Wayside Six
images.caption: Jacque LeMoyne artwork

data.bodyText:
Archeologists agree that the Timucua lived in the wooded area in the distance. The trees provided wood for fuel and shelter, while fresh water springs supplied water. 

In 1564 illustrator Jacque LeMoyne came to Florida as part of a French expedition. His vivid drawings depicting Timucuan life are our only visual record of this now-extinct cvilization that occupied much of Florida for thousands of years.

data.title: Seminole Rest Wayside, What Do You Think?
data.listingDescription: The Seminole Rest wayside two explores the life ways of the Timucua and how they shellfish harvested in Mosquito Lagoon.

images.altText: Seminole Rest Kiosk Two
images.title: Seminole Rest Kiosk Two
images.caption: The second stop along the Seminole Rest path.

data.bodyText:
Archeologists believe that women and children gathered shellfish along the shore, using their feet and hands or digging with sticks or rakes. Meanwhile, the men fished in the deeper waters of the Mosquito Lagoon or Atlantic Ocean, using fish traps, nets, barbed arrows, or spears. 

What did the Timucua look for when choosing a location a location to obtaine food? What might cause them to return to the same spot repeatedly? Was this a clam-processing site as archeologists suggest or could it have had other purposes?
