data.title: [Sign] Extended Family Wayside #107k

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Extended Family Wayside. 1 minute. A color image of a forest fills this entire three-foot-tall angled, metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Extended Family. Life and death form a continuum in the forest community. This fallen Douglass fir serves as a nurse log for new generations of trees. Western redcedar and western hemlock seedlings sprout on the log, above the competition of the forest floor. In time, these trees may survive as a colonnade, their roots encircling the shape of the vanished nurse log. In the foreground of the image on the left and right are lower trunk sections of light brown trees, their bases not flat to the ground. Instead, like curved fingers touching a flat surface, long, thick, downward arched roots ring the bottom of the trees, elevating them above ground level. Green moss grows on the roots and green ferns dot the ground. In the background, the dense green forest extends into the distance.

data.title: [Sign] First Residents Wayside #107e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: First Residents Wayside. 1 minute A color illustration of a woman standing next to a body of water fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel on the shoreline of Lake Crescent. Text on the left side reads: First Residents. The Klallam name for Lake Crescent sounds like tsulthmut. Stories and traditions of the Klallam and Quileute people tell us that American Indians maintained a long and intimate association with Lake Crescent. The lakeshore served as a meeting place, and area tribes gathered here to trade and join in ceremonies. On the right, a woman facing left stands on the lake shore. She has long dark hair pushed to the back, light brown skin, dark eyebrows and high cheekbones. She stares forward with a look of determination on her face. She wears a brown and black woven shawl, a mid-calf length skirt of the same material, and dark boots. A large open weave basket holding a piece of wood hangs down her back, supported by a decorated strap wrapped across her forehead. To the woman’s right at the water’s edge is a wooden canoe. Beyond, is the green-blue lake and mist shrouded mountains in the distance.

data.title: [Sign] Forest Elders Wayside #107n

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Forest Elders Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Forest Elders. Ancient trees, grand and majestic, contribute to the wealth of wildlife habitats found here. Large standing dead trees and downed logs provide homes and feeding sites for dozens of animals. The mixture of different species and ages of trees creates a multi-layered canopy that shelters wildlife from rain, wind and sun. These essential characteristics of old-growth community may take 250 years to develop. In the foreground of the image on the left is the wide base and lower trunk section of a large tree. It has rough textured dark brown bark, speckled with green moss and is labeled, Douglas-fir. To the right and further back in the center of the forest is a tree labeled Western redcedar. Its bark is reddish-brown and stringy in texture. On the right, is the trunk of a Western hemlock, its bark grey and rough. On the forest floor, green ferns grown between pieces of scattered wood.

data.title: [Sign] Forest Healers Wayside #107m

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Forest Healers Wayside. 1 minute. A color image of a two tree stumps in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the right reads: Forest Healers. Red alders have reclaimed this skid road, a relic of past logging activity. Alders are pioneer species on distributed soils. These quick-growing trees add valuable nitrogen and humus to forest soils and prevent erosion. Eventually, western hemlock and western redcedars will tower above these short-lived hardwoods. Several centuries from now, a mature old-growth forest could stand here. The image shows two short, dark tree stumps, one on the left and one on the right, partially covered with green moss. The top of each stump is flat and horizontal exposing the reddish- brown wood on the inside. On the right-side edge are jagged, vertical splinters ripped from the tree as it fell. Reddish-brown wood chips are piled up at the foot of each stump. On the forest floor, green ferns grow around remnants of fallen trees. In the background, a sparse forest of tall and short trees is shrouded in a gray-white mist, a blue-sky peeking through.

data.title: [Sign] Moments in Time Wayside #107h

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Moments in Time Trail Wayside. 1 minute The color image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a lake with still water flanked on the right by a hill with tall dark pine trees and on the left and rear by the slope of a tall mountain. Text reads: Moments in Time Trail. Shaped by time and water, Barnes Point punctuates the south shore of glacially carved Lake Crescent. This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. A trail map is provided below and at four other entry points. Please return it after use. These interpretive exhibits were provided by the Rob Reed and Lena Sharpe Memorial Foundation.

data.title: [Sign] Primeval Fir Wayside #107L

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Primeval Fir Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a tree falling in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel located in front of a weathered, decaying stump of a large tree. Text on the right reads: Primeval Fir. Before it crashed to the ground, this Douglas-fir measured 35 feet in circumference. Can you guess how tall it grew? Across the trail, its contemporary still stands. Both trees took root in the ashes of fires that burned here 500 to 700 years ago. Douglas-fir seedlings often sprout after fire or wind has swept through the forest. The image shows a stormy forest scene with heavy rain falling diagonally. On the left, the trunk of a dark brown tree has split away from its base and is dropping to the right. At the break, the inside of the tree is revealed, its tan wood splintering under the force of the collapsing trunk. In the background, stand trees with long, thin branches and green needles.

This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. data.title: Prairie Village Santa Fe Trail Park
data.listingDescription: Prairie Village Ruts marks the location of the Oregon, California, and Santa Fe Trails in the form of rounded depressions in the ground called swales. These swales were once part of a well-defined path, most equivalent to a modern day dirt road, that was created as thousands of oxen, cattle, and wagons traveled across the land. They eroded and compacted the ground, which created ruts. Over time, the ruts were weathered into the more gently sloping swales visible today.

images.altText: A grass meadow surrounded in a city park contains a shallow, long u-shaped depression left by wagons traveling the Oregon Trail
images.caption: Swale at Prairie Village Ruts Site

data.bodyText:
Harmon Park

Prairie Village Ruts marks the location of the Oregon, California, and Santa Fe Trails in the form of rounded depressions in the ground called swales. These swales were once part of a well-defined path, most equivalent to a modern day dirt road, that was created as thousands of oxen, cattle, and wagons traveled across the land. They eroded and compacted the ground, which created ruts. Over time, the ruts were weathered into the more gently sloping swales visible today. Trail ruts and swales are invaluable because they mark the actual route used by emigrants over 160 years ago.

Site Information

 Today, the Prairie Village Ruts are part of a four acre city park. In addition to the ruts, the park contains interpretive signs that tell the Trail story, a pavilion, and a playground. Amenities include restrooms, a large fireplace, cooking grills, and picnic tables. 

Exhibits: Take a look at the Kansas City, from Missouri to the West exhibit.

Exhibit Audio Description available

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Santa Fe National Historic Trail
data.audioDescription:
Prairie Village Santa Fe Trail Park. 221 words

A sidewalk runs parallel to the parking lot. Going left, it leads to a semicircular area bounded by a low stone wall with a wayside sign, titled "Prairie Highway." An illustration shows a large covered wagon pulled by oxen. The sign reads in part, "Over 100 years ago, the gentle grassy depression in front of you was one of the most important highways in North America. Here, you'd see wagon trains on the Santa Fe Trail winding through a rolling landscape covered with thick, waist-high prairie grasses. Imagine thousands of trade wagons rumbling and creaking back and forth between Missouri and New Mexico. Wagons - and the hooves of the oxen and mules that pulled them - wore this road into the earth. By the 1840s, emigrants bound for Oregon and California Trails wore it even deeper. Here, the prairie is gone. Wind and rain have smoothed the rough dirt road into a gentle swale - a subtle reminder of a once-great highway."

By moving around the stone wall and walking out onto the grassy lawn you may be able to feel the swale that crosses from left to right, although it is very shallow. About 40 feet out, on the other side of the swale, is a cement post with a small marker for the Santa Fe Trail.

data.title: [Sign] Marymere Falls Trail Wayside #100a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Marymere Falls Trail Wayside. 1 minute In this six-foot-tall upright two-legged brown metal frame is a large informational panel with a green map across the top showing the black dashed line for the Marymere Falls Trail. Text below reads: Marymere Falls Trail. Through more than a half-mile of lowland forest the trail climbs gradually, then steeply for the last eight-mile to Marymere Falls. Average hiking time round trip is one and one-half hours. The path takes you to the edge of the Olympic wilderness. From a human-shaped world you are about to step into terrain dominated by other forces. There are five other short, easy Touch of Wilderness hikes in the park at Staircase, Pioneer Visitor Center, Soleduck, La Push and Ozette. Each trail enters a different environment: coastal, river and lowland forests, waterfalls and tidepools. To the left of the text is a black and white drawing of a tall waterfall cascading down a dark rocky slope to a pool below. Below the text, is the black and white pine branch and pinecone graphic logo for touch of wilderness.

data.title: [Sign] Spruce Railroad Wayside #107d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Wayside. 2 minutes A color illustration of a train and tracks along the near shore of a lake fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Spruce Railroad. Imagine the continuous clank of steel upon steel echoing across Lake Crescent. To secure spruce lumber for World War 1 warplanes, a railroad was built in 1918 along the far shore of the lake. Soldiers and civilians toiled for five months, cutting two tunnels and laying rails in record time. The war ended just weeks before the railroad was completed, but it was used to haul timber until 1954. Today, a hiking and biking trail follows this route. On the right side of the panel, the front of a gray metal tube-shaped steam train emerges from a dark tunnel cut through a brown rocky mountain slope. The tunnel opening is framed on the top and sides with thick wooden timbers. The train travels towards us on two metal rails atop many squared off wooden beams laid perpendicular to the rails. On top of the train, a smokestack belches thick dark grey smoke. The flat face of the train is round with a smaller round door and headlight in the center. Below, is a platform with handrail, both the width of the train. On the bottom, a forward angled metal grill with vertical bars, slightly wider than the train tracks, almost touches the tracks. On the left side of the panel is the lake, its blue water and surrounding mountains partially obscured by thick light gray mist.

data.title: [Sign] The Giving Tree Wayside #107c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: The Giving Tree Wayside. 2 minutes A color illustration of a Pileated Woodpecker clinging to a tree in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: The Giving Tree. When a tree dies, insects and fungi invade. This grand fir has been chipped away by woodpeckers and other insectivores searching for insects and larvae. Large rectangular holes made by pileated woodpeckers often serve as homes for other animals. More than one third of the bird species common to Northwest forests, as well as other small animals, nest in these cavities. Can you think of any? On the right side of the panel, a right-facing, mostly black, pileated woodpecker is vertically anchored by its four toed clawed feet to a light brown tree trunk with several holes. Crowning the birds entire head is a cap of bright red feathers that end at the back of the head in an upward pointing crest. Its round eye is yellow, and its tan beak is long and pointed. Above the eye is an upward curving white stripe. Below the eye, beginning at the beak, a bold white stripe runs to the back of the head, then curves downward ending at the chest. Under this stripe on the bird’s cheek is a patch of red, then below this, another white strip on the underside of the head. The scene in the center and left side of the panel, shows a dark, dense green and brown forest. Green moss grows on some of the trees.

data.title: [Sign] Visitor Information Panel #100b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Visitor Information Panel. 30 seconds Along the flat, gravel path from the parking lot to the restrooms is a large visitor information panel in a roof covered kiosk on the right. In the center of the panel is a map of the Northern Olympic Peninsula in gray surrounded by blue water. Color coded symbols on the map are used to indicate visitor information locations in green; recreational opportunities in purple; commercial services in red; and 31 places of interest throughout the area in orange. Above and below the map is text providing information about the natural and cultural history of the peninsula, local communities and towns, trails, and other recreational opportunities.

data.title: [Sign] Wild Things Wayside #107b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Wild Things Wayside. 1 minute A color illustration of a stream and otter fills this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel here on the shoreline of Lake Crescent. Text on the left side of the panel reads: Wild Things. Elusive bald eagles, black-tailed deer, river otters and freshwater clams inhabit this area. Two unique varieties of trout, Beardslee (rainbow) and Crescentic (cutthroat), are found only in Lake Crescent. The interface of water and land creates a diversity of wildlife habitats. The illustration shows a narrow stream flowing from left to right between steep banks of moss-covered rocks and ferns. A small waterfall cascades over rocks, then the stream becomes flat. Here, a brown river otter crosses the stream from right to left, its two front feet in the stream and its hind feet on the stream bank. The otter is long and narrow with a long thin tail, flattened head with a small dark oval shaped eye, and a small, rounded ear set back on the side of the head. Its short flat snout has a black nose above the mouth and white whiskers on each side.

data.bodyText: A National Park Service sign now marks the entrance to the LBJ Ranch. In 1972, the Johnsons donated approximately 600 acres of their ranch to the National Park Service.
data.audioDescription: A two-lane paved road heads west through an open white, metal gate. White rail fences extend to the north and south from the gate. On the north side of the road, approximately 5 feet from the pavement, is a stone framework. Hanging from the center of the frame is a sign that says "Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park." Attached to the stone column to the left of the sign is a National Park Service arrowhead. Further ahead, and closer to the gate and fence, a second smaller, metal sign stands on the north side of the road. It reads "LBJ Ranch Operating Hours, 9:00 am to 4:30 pm, LBJ Ranch tour permits issued at LBJ State Park Visitor Center (1.4 miles west on Ranch Road 1).

data.title: Station Road Bridge River Access
data.listingDescription: Access the river via the Station Road Bridge Trailhead in Brecksville. A mowed path leads from the southeast corner of the parking lot to the river.

images.altText: A green kayak rests by a trail sign overlooking the junction of two waterways. Two people pull an or
images.title: Station Road Bridge River Access
images.caption: The boat access on the Cuyahoga River just upstream of Station Road Bridge.

data.bodyText:
This site allows access to a section of the Cuyahoga River Water Trail that is suitable for beginners. A mowed path leads from the southeast corner of the parking lot to the river. Two dams were removed downstream in 2020, improving paddler safety and lowering the water level here.

Things to Know for Paddlers

  • Paved parking lot, restrooms, picnic tables, drinking water, hiking and biking trails, train station.
  • River-related exhibits near the trailhead kiosk and along the Towpath Trail.
  • View of Station Road Bridge is popular with photographers.
  • Dropoff/pickup option on Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad during Bike Aboard season with fee. Board downstream at Rockside Station and ride to Brecksville Station. Paddle to Lock 39 (located next to Rockside Station), walk to Rockside Station parking lot and drive back to pick up your boat.
  • Pedal/paddle option. Use the Towpath Trail to bike/run/walk back from Lock 39 Trailhead.
  • Class I downstream paddle to Lock 39 involves one permanent hazard.

Known Hazards

Downstream:

  • Before Lock 39 Trailhead, tall metal pylons in the river can create log jams. Portage right if needed. Know the river flow before you go. Check river gauges.
data.audioDescription: Station Road Bridge River Access. 244 words The Cuyahoga River Water Trail access at Station Road Bridge is located on the west bank of the river. The mowed path to the river access starts in the southeast corner of the parking lot at Station Road Bridge Trailhead. There is a sign at the beginning that states vehicles are prohibited. Closer to the river access is another sign that provides directions on “River Use and Hazards.” The access point is to the left of the sign. There are large rocks to use as stepping stones down to the riverbank. The terrain is flat through the field and becomes uneven as you approach the river access. The path does get muddy after wet weather. When you reach the access point, the river will be in front of you. The ground is dirt with different sized rocks along the bank. The area to the direct right and left of the access point is steep and has grass and trees. The Towpath Trail is visible directly across the river. Station Road Bridge is visible downriver to your left. To your right is an open flat area with loose rocks and dirt with Chippewa Creek beyond. To the right and behind you is a dark blue sign that has the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo with “Station Road Bridge.” Underneath the text on the sign is a lighter blue shaded area with the number “21.0” indicating the river mile. End of Description

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Follow the marked path southeast to the river.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Provides paddlers with access to the Cuyahoga River Water Trail.

data.title: Lake Crescent - East Beach
data.listingDescription: East Beach is a scenic picnic area on the lake shore, with tables, fire pits, and an accessible outhouse.

images.altText: A glittering lake with green hills on all sides.

data.bodyText: East Beach is a scenic picnic area on the lake shore, with tables, fire pits, and an accessible outhouse.
data.audioDescription: Lake Crescent – East Beach. 2 minutes A brown wooden and white sign supported by log posts reads, Welcome to Lake Crescent, Olympic National Park. The Park Service arrowhead logo is attached to the sign. Another sign reads, East Beach Day Use Area. Alcohol and Glass Prohibited. Symbols on the sign indicate picnicking and dogs on leash are permitted, but camping is not. The gravel parking area is bordered on the right by forest, on the left by the lake and beach, and straight ahead by a picnic area with tables. Large boulders on the ground separate the parking lot from the picnic area. At the end of the parking lot on the forest side is a brown, an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom with a vault toilet. Entry is on the left front side of the building. Garbage bins are located to the left of the restroom. On the beach is a boat rental station with canoes lined up along the shoreline. A sign reads, Floatation Vest Required. A chalkboard notes the cost to rent a boat. A wooden and concrete pier, stretching out into the lake, has a railing on each side up until the last 10 feet. A swimming area in the lake is defined by a string of floating, orange buoys. Forested mountains border the lake on all sides.

data.title: Lake Crescent Lodge - Marymere Falls Trailhead

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

data.audioDescription: Lake Crescent Lodge - Marymere Falls Trailhead. 30 seconds A brown and white sign has an upward pointing arrow and the text, Marymere Falls. No Pets, Weapons, or Vehicles. At the trailhead, the gravel path gently slopes uphill and enters a dense forest of tall trees, their limbs hanging with moss. Tall green ferns and other understory plants line the trail.

data.bodyText: Explore Lake Crescent by boat, kayak, or paddleboard. Pay for boat rental inside the main lodge building, then head to the rental building.
data.audioDescription: Boat Rental. 1 minute A brown, shingled building with green trim houses the boat rental office. A white sign with black text attached to the door reads, Restricted Area, Authorized Personnel Only. To the left of the door a green sign attached to the building reads, Boat Rental. Row. Canoe. Peddle. P.F.D.s included. To the right of the door under a window, another green sign reads, Water activities at your own risk. At the water’s edge, a sign reads, Boat Rental. Pay launch fee at lodge. No Swimming. Beyond the sign, a flat, downward slanting metal bridge with handrails extends out to a low floating pier where rental boats are secured on either side. A second bridge and pier are located off to the right of the boat rental area. The lake is surrounded by green forested mountains.

data.title: Start the Freedom Trail
data.listingDescription: Begin your exploration of Boston's storied, complicated, and multi-faceted history at the start of the red-bricked Freedom Trail.

images.altText: three pairs of feet standing around the start of two lines of red brick on ground.
images.title: Start of the Freedom Trail brick
images.caption: Begin the Freedom Trail on Boston Common

data.bodyText: Welcome to Boston’s Freedom Trail. Originally designed in the 1950s, the Freedom Trail is an iconic symbol of Boston. Its red brick line snakes through some of the oldest parts of this City, leading visitors to notable historic sites in the Downtown, North End, and Charlestown neighborhoods of Boston. The trail introduces visitors to Boston's storied, complicated, and multi-faceted history. While many sites are primarily recognized for their role in the American Revolution, all the sites on the Freedom Trail have stood as the backdrop of subsequent social, political, and religious movements, controversies, and challenges.
data.audioDescription: The beginning of a red-brick line that consists of two rows of bricks side-by-side. This line weaves through the city of Boston. In some places the line is made of red-paint instead of brick.

data.title: Smoky Bottom Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Starting just past the Glines Canyon Spillway Overlook (currently accessible on foot only, about 3 miles/4.8 km beyond the Madison Falls parking lot), this 1.9 mile/3 km one way trail drops into the valley above the former dam site. As you walk across riverbanks which were under water for nearly a century, you can see how the ecosystem has begun to return to a wilder, more natural state.

images.altText: A meadow full of lupine flowers, with an old dam site in the distance.
images.caption: Riverbank lupine bloom in spring along the Smoky Bottom Trail, with a view of the former Glines Canyon Dam.

data.bodyText: Starting just past the Glines Canyon Spillway Overlook (currently accessible on foot only, about 3 miles/4.8 km beyond the Madison Falls parking lot), this 1.9 mile/3 km one way trail drops into the valley above the former dam site. As you walk across riverbanks which were under water for nearly a century, you can see how the ecosystem has begun to return to a wilder, more natural state.
data.audioDescription: Smoky Bottom Trailhead. 25 seconds This trail begins as a gravel pathway with a wooden fence on the left and a hill on the right bordered by rocks. The fence and rock border end about 40 feet from the trailhead.

data.title: Spruce Railroad Trailhead - East
data.listingDescription: Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.

images.altText: A lake shoreline, seen from the water.
images.caption: The "Devil's Punchbowl" bridge. Photo by M. Juran/NPS.

data.bodyText: Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.
data.audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Trailhead. 2 minutes A brown and white sign on the right side of the road leading to the trailhead reads, Spruce Railroad Trail Parking. In the parking area is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom with a vault toilet. Entry is on the left front side of the building. Garbage bins are in front of the restroom on the right. Across the gravel pathway at the trailhead stand three, vertical, yellow poles spaced about five feet apart. A brown and white sign on the left side of the trail reads, Warning. Low level light in tunnel. Stay to the right. Use reflective devices. Walk bicycles through tunnel. About five feet beyond the warning sign, also on the left, is a covered bulletin board with posted park information. One notice reads: The Spruce Railroad Trail connects the North Shore and Lyre River trailheads. The trail runs on or next to the World War 1 Spruce Railroad bed and offers excellent views of Lake Crescent. From the west end, a six-and-a-half-mile paved extension leads farther west to Highway 101. This section is wheelchair accessible. Bicycles, horses and dogs are allowed on this trail. Dogs must be on leash at all times. Motorcycles and other motor vehicles are not allowed. Bicyclists must ride in control and at a safe speed. Watch out for ticks and poison ivy. This is a day use area only. Other notices include information about backcountry safety, a warning about poison oak, and fishing regulations.

data.title: Storm King Boat Launch

images.altText: A boat ramp and a dock extending into a bright blue lake.

data.bodyText: Dock and boat launch on Lake Crescent.
data.audioDescription: Storm King Boat Launch. 1 minute At the edge of the parking lot, a wooden dock extends out into the lake. Connected to the end of this dock is a downward sloping metal bridge that connects to a second wooden dock, extending the structure even further into the lake. Side rails on the wooden docks are about 18-inches high. The railings on the metal ramp are about 4 feet high. The second dock sits lower in the water than the first dock and has a low railing at the end. Overlapping green, forested mountains surround the lake. To the right of the dock, a ridged, asphalt boat ramp slopes into the water. A sign next to the ramp reads, Olympic National Park. Notice to Boaters. The introduction of non-native plants and water-borne species into Lake Crescent is prohibited. If your boat was last in waters other than this lake, removing contaminants from the hull, bilge and engine is required prior to launch. 36 CFR 2.14

data.title: Storm King Ranger Station
data.listingDescription: Open in summer as staffing allows, with information, activities, and ranger programs.

images.altText: A cabin with a stone chimney among trees and mist. Sign in front reads "Storm King Ranger Station."
images.caption: The Storm King Ranger Station.

data.bodyText: Open in summer as staffing allows, with information, activities, and ranger programs.
data.audioDescription: Storm King Ranger Station. 4 minutes From the parking lot, a flat path leads to the log cabin Ranger Station. The building is two-stories with two second floor A-shaped dormers sitting midway up the wooden shingled roof. A red brick chimney extends above the roof in the center of the building and a grey, stone chimney on the cabin’s right wall rises above the roof line. A raised front porch with four steps and handrails provides access to the centrally located front door. Windows trimmed in white are on either side of the door. Attached to the cabin and directly adjacent to the door on the right and left, are wooden boxes holding park brochures and other information. Inside, the wooden walls of the cabin are reddish gold in color with prominent dark scattered knots. The wood floor is similar in color. In the center of the room, interpretive material such as tactile casts of animal footprints and touchable animal pelts are laid out on a table with chairs. Hanging on the wall is a black and white historic photograph of nine women and five men aboard a long white wooden boat sitting low in the water. A canopy covers two-thirds of the boat. The boat engine’s chimney rises above the canopy. The women wear ankle length, high collared, long sleeve patterned dresses and wide brimmed hats. The men wear white long-sleeved shirts, dark vests, and pants. One woman holds a guitar. A sign below the photograph reads: Lady of the Lake. Ferries were the only means of transportation at Lake Crescent during the turn of the century. Lady of the Lake, one of the ferries, transported passengers and goods from the East Beach area to Fairholme. It could reach a speed of eight miles per hour and frequently stopped at resorts around the lake. Ferries remained in service until shortly after 1922, when the road around the south shore was completed. A taxidermied trout also hangs on the wall, its pointed mouth opened, exposing sharp teeth. The skin of the trout is gray on top, pink and lightly spotted on the side, and light tan on the belly. Along the spine are two fins and along the belly, four fins. The V-shaped tail fin is spotted. A sign below the fish reads: Beardslee Trout. The Beardslee trout brough considerable acclaim to lake Crescent as early as the 1890s. A subspecies of rainbow trout, it is unique to the lake. The tout is named after Admiral Lesley A. Beardslee who initiated scientific interest in this species. The trout on display weighed 16 ¾ pounds. The largest Beardslee ever caught tipped the scales at 23 pounds. Next to the text is a small black and white photographic portrait of a man from the shoulders up facing slightly left with the caption, Admiral Beardslee. He is light complexioned with a dark, bushy moustache, thick dark eyebrows, close cut gray hair, and dark eyes. His dark jacket has a tall collar adorned with two white stars and an anchor. His black hat has a round side band with military insignia on the front, flat crown, and short front brim. Next to the sign is a taxidermied owl with brown and white feathers, big, round, dark eyes, and a short yellow beak.

Unfortunately, some visitors forget this and have fed birds on Mount Storm King. When birds become habituated they forget how to be wild and can even become aggressive. This is not the pla

images.altText: A lake with mountains rising beyond the shore.
images.caption: Mount Storm King, seen across Lake Crescent. Photo by M. Juran/NPS.

data.bodyText: The Mount Storm King trail branches off from the Marymere Falls trail and switchbacks up 2,000 feet in 2.2 miles (610 meters in 3.5 km) - an intense, steep ascent! If you venture to the top, please: Don't feed that Canada jay! In national parks, keeping wildlife wild is part of our mission. Unfortunately, some visitors forget this and have fed birds on Mount Storm King. When birds become habituated they forget how to be wild and can even become aggressive. This is not the place for a fairy tale princess moment...especially if you don't want to be fined for breaking park laws!
data.audioDescription: Storm King Trailhead. 30 seconds Caution. The trail surface here is very uneven due to protruding tree roots and rocks. A brown and white sign at the trailhead reads, Storm King Trail. Ferns and other low growing plants line the trail and carpet the forest floor below tall trees.

data.title: Elko Hot Hole
data.listingDescription: Hot Hole, named after its round and reportedly deep shape. This geologic wonder has been known about longer than Elko has been a town! It was noted in reports, dated as early as the 1830s, by explorers that passed through the area. Later, emigrants and miners following the same paths, which were now known as the California Trail, wrote about the Hot Hole in their journals.
data.bodyText:
The hot spring in front of you is known as Hot Hole, named after its round and reportedly deep shape. This geologic wonder has been known about longer than Elko has been a town! It was noted in reports, dated as early as the 1830s, by explorers that passed through the area. Later, emigrants and miners following the same paths, which were now known as the California Trail, wrote about the Hot Hole in their journals.

They also wrote about the other hot springs they discovered that are less than a quarter mile from here. To the south, and up the hill, lies Elko Hot Springs, a cluster of springs that was the site of a resort in the late 1800s. To the northeast of the Hot Hole, on the banks of the Humboldt River, lies another three hot springs. They are positioned in an east to west line, forming a ribbon of springs. None of these “ribbon” hot springs are named, but all of them, and Elko Hot Springs, were visited by California Trail travelers.

Site Information

Currently, Elko Hot Springs is located on private property. Respect this and do not enter without permission from the landowner. The cluster of unnamed hot springs has neither directions to them nor their locations marked. Also, some of the land is private property. For information about these springs, contact the California Trail Interpretive Center.

Exhibit Audio Description Available 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

California National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail

data.title: Mill Creek Park, Independence MO

images.altText: A picnic shelter with a blue roof, in a city park, under a blue sky.
images.title: Mill Creek Park
images.caption: Visit Mill Creek Park in Independence, Missouri.

data.bodyText:
Mill Creek Trail - Follow along the same path traveled by thousands of homesteaders, prospectors, and entrepreneurs. The Missouri River carried them to the Upper Independence landing two miles north of here. With their wagons loaded, they headed to town in Independence for final preparations. These the first miles of the overland journey to California, Oregon, and Santa Fe.

Site Information

Available Facilities: This park is situated between the historic routes of the three overland trails. Today, visitors can enjoy sports fields, picnic shelters, and play areas. Follow the paved trail south to parallel the original trail routes established during the 1800s. The paved path remains relatively flat leading to McCoy Park.

Exhibits: There are three exhibits to learn more about the National Historic Trails in this area.

Exhibit Audio Description available


Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

data.title: [Sign] Alien Plants Wayside #107g

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Alien Plants Wayside. 1 minute The color background image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel shows a man in a green grassy area using a tool to remove a small tree. Text on the right reads: Alien Plants. Can you identify any non-native plants here? When settlers came to Lake Crescent, they brought their favorite flora. Other exotics were accidentally introduced and now nearly a quarter of the Olympic Peninsula’s plant species are non-native. Park biologists monitor the spread of these plants and try to remove those that present the greatest threat to natural ecosystems. The man has dark hair and beard and wears a green National Park Service ballcap, a white sweatshirt, green pants, brown boots and leather gloves. He is grasping the top of an orange, long handled tool with a horizontal hook at the end. Standing with his feet apart, he hooks the trunk of the small tree at its base. The tree is a little taller than the man and has many branches with yellow leaves. It is labeled, Scot’s broom.

data.title: [Sign] A Window in Time Wayside #107i

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: A Window in Time Wayside. 2 minutes On the edge of the trail in a forest of moss-covered trees, is a three-foot-tall angled wayside panel titled, A Window In Time. Filling the background is a color illustration of a ferry boat on a blue lake with mountains in the background. The ferry is long with a railing around the edge. In the center is an enclosed cabin with windows. Along the side of the cabin is a wooden water wheel. In the foreground on the lake shore, is a woman, her back to us, with long dark hair, wearing an ankle length red skirt, long sleeved white bouse and a white wide brimmed hat. She stands under a tall, wooden-lattice gate-like structure looking out toward the ferry. At the top of the structure is the word, Rosemary, reversed, so it may be read correctly from the water. Text reads: Imagine yourself here in 1920, traveling by paddle wheel ferry across lake Crescent. From the deck you view a gateway announcing “Rosemary,” a rustic inn bordered by several handcrafted cabins. Today, Rosemary houses Nature Bridge, and educational facility offering environmental learning programs for students of all ages.

data.title: [Sign] Early Logging Wayside #107j

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Early Logging Wayside. 1 minute A color image of two men sawing down a huge tree fills this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Early Logging. Can you find the clues? Notched springboard holes and flat-topped stumps indicate these ancient giants were cut during the early 1900s. Using only hand tools, woodsmen relied on springboards to lift them above the buttressed bases of large trees. Steam donkeys, horses or ox teams pulled the downed logs along greased skid roads. The image shows two men, one on each side, of an extremely large reddish-brown tree, standing on boards that have been inserted into the tree above ground level. The men wear brimmed hats, button-down long-sleeved shirts, pants, and brown leather boots. Each man holds one end of a long saw that spans the inside of a large, angled notch cut into the tree. Scattered on the ground in front of the tree are pieces of wood sawn from the notch. To the left of the men is a tree stump, its top smooth on one side and jagged on the other. Bits of woods lay around the stump. In the background is a dense forest of uncut trees, green moss hanging from the limbs.

data.title: Fairholme Restroom and Campground Registration - Loop A

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

data.bodyText: Loop A Registration
data.audioDescription: Fairholme Campground Registration Loop A. 2 minutes From the road, a paved path leads to the left short side of a rectangular restroom building where the women’s room entrance located. A paved path spanning the front of the building leads to the men’s room on the right short side of the building. The building sits on a slight hill. To reach an information area in front of the restroom, a stairway with five steps near the center of the building is available. The path from the road also leads to the lower level. Here, there is a water station and a roof-covered bulletin board with information about boating, fishing, and swimming on the front and campground information including the campground registration board on the back. The registration board is a vertical framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the left of the board is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board on the left is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope.

data.title: Station 5 Panholes

images.altText: Examples of 6 panholes ranging in size from a saucer to a dinner plate.
images.title: Panholes

data.bodyText:
Panholes 

Panholes often contain quartz and feldspar sand as residualdetritus from in situ chemical weathering of the granite. Panholes also catch water after a storm and when snow melts.  

One of the larger panholes at City of Rocks is located on top of Bath Rock. At times this panhole can hold water up to a depth of two feet. According to folklore, Bath Rock served as a place of bathing for shepherds or cowboys who remained out on the range for several days. 

In 1937-38, the Bath Tub Rock Bathing Beauty Parade was held at City of Rocks, further establishing the connection between bathing and Bath Rock.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Station 6 Intrusive Contact

images.altText: Granite slab showing examples of "contact", "veins", "Almo Pluton", and "Green Creek Complex"
images.title: Intrusive Contact

data.bodyText:
Intrusive Contact of the Almo Pluton and Green Creek Complex 

The Almo pluton originated as an intrusive body of magma and has a convoluted and sometimes obscure contact with the surrounding Green Creek Complex. Here, one can see the contact clearly. As the Almo pluton intruded, it wedged its way into weaknesses formed by bedding planes, joints and metamorphic layering. Huge slabs of the Green Creek Complex detached completely or swung down into the magma like trap doors. 

Veins are thin dikes formed by igneous intrusions into cracks. Some of the veins are made of pure quartz while others are composed of a mixture of fine-grained quartz and feldspar called aplite (seen here).
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: La Ventana Natural Arch
data.listingDescription: La Ventana Natural Arch within El Malpais National Conservation Area (Bureau of Land Management) is a spectacular natural sandstone arch just off of Highway 117 adjacent to El Malpais National Monument.

images.altText: A sidwalk leads to a sandstone cliff with a prominent arch feature within the sandstone.
images.title: La Ventana Natural Arch
images.caption: Follow the trail to La Ventana Natural Arch

data.bodyText:
La Ventana Natural Arch is New Mexico's second largest natural arch and an easy stop along Highway 117. The parking area features vault toilets and a shaded picnic area shortly down the trail. You can see excellent views of La Ventana Natural Arch from the parking area, but views only improve on the easy 1/4-mile walk up to the arch viewing point. Informational kiosks along the trail describe the area's unique geology.

To reach La Ventana Natural Arch, take exit 89 off I-40 and travel south on Highway 117 for about 18 miles. La Ventana Natural Arch is located on the east side of Highway 117 within El Malpais National Conservation Area managed by the Bureau of Land Management.
data.audioDescription: The parking area is located in a pull-off along the highway. A natural amphitheater-like canyon of 200 foot high sandstone walls surrounds the parking area. On one side of this canyon is a large sandstone arch stretching between sides of the canyon walls.

data.title: Apache Prisoners
data.listingDescription: In 1886 the US Army exiled over 400 Apaches from the Southwest to Florida and sent most of them to Fort Marion in St. Augustine. Several Pensacola citizens, however, petitioned the government to imprison Geronimo, a medicine man and warrior, and 15 other Apache men at Fort Pickens instead, separating them from their families. Prisoners worked seven-hour days clearing overgrown weeds, planting grass, and stacking cannonballs. The families were reunited at Fort Pickens in 1887.

images.altText: Black and white image of 16 Apache men sitting near a fort brick wall.
images.caption: First 16 Apache Prisoners

data.bodyText:
In 1886 the U.S. Army exiled over 400 Apaches from the Southwest to Florida and sent most of them to Fort Marion in St. Augustine. Several Pensacola citizens, however, petitioned the government to imprison Geronimo, a medicine man and warrior, and 15 other Apache men at Fort Pickens instead, separating them from their families. Prisoners worked seven-hour days clearing overgrown weeds, planting grass, and stacking cannonballs. The families were reunited at Fort Pickens in 1887. One year later all of the imprisoned Apaches were moved to Mobile because of a yellow fever scare and later to Fort Sill in Oklahoma Territory.

The US Army transported Geronimo and other Apaches by train to Florida from what is now New Mexico and Arizona.

"I was born on the prairies where the wind blew free and there was nothing to break the light of the sun. I was born where there were no enclosures."

After being captured, Geronimo never saw his homeland again. He died and was buried in 1909 at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. He remains a fascinating-and controversial-figure in American history.
data.audioDescription:
415 words
Along the dirt path near the south wall of the fort there is a slanted graphic facing the vegetation-covered mound banked against the short wall on this end of the fort. On either side the path curves around the mound towards the corners of the fort.

As you face the panel, to your right is the south wall of the fort lined on the inside by a series of rounded arched enclosures.

On the other side is a vegetation-covered mound that is banked against the front side of Battery Pensacola located in the middle of the fort ground.


Apache Prisoners.

In the lower left corner of the panel is a photograph of two rows of American Indians seated on the steep gravel bank next to a set of railroad tracks, wheels and the lower edge of railcars visible behind them. They are mostly men all with long black hair. Many wear wide-brimmed hats. Others have cloth tied around their heads. The caption reads,

"The US Army transported Geronimo (foreground, third from right) and other Apaches by train to Florida from what is now New Mexico and Arizona."

Text at upper left reads,

"In 1886 the US Army exiled over 400 Apaches from the Southwest to Florida and sent most of them to Fort Marion in St. Augustine. Several Pensacola citizens, however, petitioned the government to imprison Geronimo, a medicine man and warrior, and 15 other Apache men at Fort Pickens instead, separating them from their families. Prisoners worked seven-hour days clearing overgrown weeds, planting grass, and stacking cannonballs. The families were reunited at Fort Pickens in 1887. One year later all of the imprisoned Apaches were moved to Mobile because of a yellow fever scare and later to Fort Sill in Oklahoma Territory."

At the right is a photograph of Geronimo. He poses half kneeling, right knee on the ground, with his left elbow braced on his other knee at he holds a rifle in front of him. His black hair is parted in the middle and falls to his shoulders. At top a quote from him reads,

"I was born on the prairies where the wind blew free and there was nothing to break the light of the sun. I was born where there were no enclosures."

The caption below reads,

"After being captured, Geronimo never saw his homeland again. He died and was buried in 1909 at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. He remains a fascinating-and controversial-figure in American history."

End of Description.

data.title: Colonial power struggle
data.listingDescription: Starting in the mid 1500s the Pensacola area became a pawn in a European power struggle in the New World. Adventures from Spain, France, and Britain competed with each other to establish a foothold on the Gulf of Mexico. Spain established several settlements in the Pensacola area from 1559 to 1821. Except for brief French periods and one British colony, Spain claimed the Pensacola area until the United States acquired Florida in a treaty.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Colonial Power Struggle" in the foreground. Four black cannon in the background.
images.caption: Interpretive Panel: Colonial Power Struggle site

data.bodyText: Starting in the mid 1500s the Pensacola area became a pawn in a European power struggle in the New World. Adventures from Spain, France, and Britain competed with each other to establish a foothold on the Gulf of Mexico. Spain established several settlements in the Pensacola area from 1559 to 1821. Except for brief French periods and one British colony, Spain claimed the Pensacola area until the United States acquired Florida in a treaty.
data.audioDescription: Colonial Power Struggle. 166 words. Four cannon are laid on blocks in a row, pointing to the west along the side of the park road, each cradled on concrete mounting blocks. As you face to the west, a small parking area lies along the road to the right. Across from the parking is a "T" shaped one-story wood-frame building. It is white with a green roof and a wide covered porch wrapping all the way around the building. To the east and west lie more buildings, smaller, but in a similar style. As you face to the east, a large cannon on top of the walls of Fort Pickens can be seen.The cannon are 12 feet long. The one at the north end, farthest to the left as you stand at the muzzles, has no markings. The other three each have a British royal insignia in their middle. This consists of a crown at the top with ornate initials below, a "G" and an "R."End of Description.

data.title: Converting A Cannon
data.listingDescription: Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the US Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bor

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign in front of a large black cannon. Brick Fort Pickens walls in the background.
images.caption: Converting A Cannon Site

data.bodyText:
Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the U.S. Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bore.

Keep off the Cannon. For your safety and to help preserve this historic cannon, do not climb on the gun barrel.
data.audioDescription:
304 words
This spot is located in the northern part of the parade ground about halfway between the entrance the black structure of the Pensacola Battery. Cradled on a concrete mount is a 12-foot-long cannon. The open bore, which points towards the east is about two and a half feet off the ground. A sign asks, "Please stay off the cannon," but feel free to touch.

On either side of the mount is a broken piece of a cannon bore. The one on the left has ridges running down the length of the bore. The one on the right is smooth on the inside.

Interpretive panel: Converting a Cannon.

Text at the upper left of this panel reads,

"Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the US Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bore.

"Keep off the Cannon. For your safety and to help preserve this historic cannon, do not climb on the gun barrel."

At the upper right is a photograph of the cannon in front of the panel looking down the bore. The grooves and ridges running the length of the inside can be clearly seen. The caption reads,

"Rifled barrel inside a smoothbore."

At the bottom of the panel is a diagram showing a lengthwise cross section of a cannon with measurements of the bore and other parts. A label on the right side reads,

"8-inch Rifle - converted. Breech Insertion."

End of Description.

data.title: Massive Smoothbore
data.listingDescription: A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannon ever developed-was installed here in 1868 but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8-, 10-, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880s. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighin

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Massive Smoothbore" in front of an open field and brick archways.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Interpretive Panel: Massive Smoothbore

data.bodyText: A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannons ever developed. It was installed here in 1868, but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8, 10, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880's. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid 450-pound shot. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction.
data.audioDescription:
466 words
Along the dirt path near the south wall of the fort there is a slanted graphic panel mounted on the side away from the wall. Standing facing the panel gives a view back across the remaining bit of the original open space at this end of the fort which is now partially taken up by the long mound which is the sand and vegetation-covered front of Battery Pensacola. Along the left is the line of arched openings along one of the fort's south walls, ending at the bastion located at the west-facing point. Sitting on top there, pointing to the west, is a huge black cannon mounted on a rust-red metal carriage.

At the bottom of this panel is a historical photograph showing a group of men around a large cannon mounted on a large metal carriage and pointing to the left. The caption reads,

"A gun crew at Fort Warren in Boston, Mass., loads a Rodman. The cannon, designed by Thomas Jefferson Rodman, was first cast in 1860.

Labels on the photograph identify the different elements. One stands at the rear of the large cannon, where its diameter is almost equal to his height. He leans over to look at a small rod sticking up for the top of the cannon. The label reads,

"Gunner using sight to aim cannon."

At the front of the cannon one man holds a long rod with a round black sponge on its end. Next to him two other men pass a white sack which holds the powder charge. Another man stands waiting below the cannon's bore holding the long ramrod. Near the rear of the canon four men hold a metal bar, two at each end, with a large cannon ball attached to the middle. A label reads,

""Shell hooks and carrying bar for moving cannonballs."

At lower left is a pyramid-shaped pile of cannon ball, four wide and four high. The top cannonball has a rectangular object sitting on top of it. The label reads,

"Cannonball attached to sabot, which prevented it from rolling in barrel."

Next to the stack is a square metal box called a pass box.

Text at the top reads,

"A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannon ever developed-was installed here in 1868 but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8-, 10-, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880s. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid 450-pound shot. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction."

End of Description.

data.title: Carmel Mission
data.listingDescription: Mission San Carlos Borromeo del Río Carmelo, or Misión de San Carlos Borromeo de Carmelo, first built in 1797, is one of the most authentically restored Roman Catholic mission churches in California. Located at the mouth of Carmel Valley, California, it is on the National Register of Historic Places and is a National Historic Landmark.

images.credit: Photo by Burkhard Mücke, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=79081037
images.altText: Carmel Mission
images.title: Carmel Mission
images.caption: Carmel Mission in Carmel, California.

tags: Discover our Shared Heritage Travel Itineraries
data.bodyText:
By the late 1700s and early 1800s, Spain extended its New World Empire by establishing permanent settlements on the west coast of North America. In order to colonize Alta (Upper) California, the Spanish constructed presidios (forts) and missions. In total, the Spanish established four presidios and 21 missions throughout Alta California. The Carmel Mission (San Carlos Borroméo de Carmelo Mission) was the second of Spain’s missions and is today a National Historic Landmark. As at many of the historic Spanish missions that still exist throughout California, visitors can tour the restored Carmel Mission.

On June 3, 1770, Captain Gaspar de Portola and Franciscan Father Junípero Serra founded the Carmel Mission and the Presidio of Monterey beside Monterey Bay. Over the course of the next year, presidio soldiers often mistreated the local American Indians living in the area. The American Indians, who associated the mission with the presidio, became leery of Father Serra and his attempts at converting them to Christianity.

In August of 1771, Father Serra moved the mission to nearby Carmel because it offered better agricultural land and a safer political environment for the growing mission. In this new location, the mission thrived. It was closer to fresh water and land more suitable for growing crops. Importantly, it was removed from the tense environment surrounding the presidio. While construction progress was slow at first, the mission eventually had temporary structures including dwellings, a storeroom, and a wooden church.

Carmel Mission became the headquarters for Father Serra and Spain’s expanding California mission system. From Carmel Mission, Father Serra directed the building of seven other missions in California. Father Serra passed away at the mission on August 28, 1784. Today, visitors to the restored Carmel Mission can see the room in which Father Serra slept and where he passed away. Father Serra’s grave is below the mission’s present church altar.
During Father Serra’s time at Carmel Mission, the mission buildings were of wood and mud and then eventually of adobe. These first structures were temporary and lasted only as long as their roofs could protect them from the elements. In 1793, Father Lausen, Father Serra’s successor, supervised the construction of a more permanent stone church, which visitors to the mission can see today.

Laborers quarried sandstone from the nearby Santa Lucia Mountains to construct the church on the site of the original adobe church. The church has two dissimilar towers flanking a round-arched portal. The bell tower, which exhibits Spanish-Moorish influence, has a dome surmounted by a wrought iron cross. At the height of its use, the church had as many as seven large-scale side altarpieces, over 20 statues, and a large crucifix flanking statues of Our Lady and St. John. The church’s interior wooden tunnel vault, shaped in a parabolic arch, is unique among the California mission churches. The church is also unique because it was the first of three California mission churches built from stone – the rest of the mission churches are of adobe.

The mission continued to thrive under Father Lausen’s leadership. He directed the construction of additional adobe buildings around the property. Today, the reconstructed mission buildings sit on top of the foundations of those Father Lausen directed to be constructed. Father Lausen passed away in 1803 and rests beside Father Serra.

By the early 1820s, a series of events negatively affected life at the mission. Sickness, death, and depredation by the military overwhelmed the mission throughout this time. In 1821, Mexico gained its independence from Spain and Alta California became a part of Mexico. The Mexican government did not have the necessary financial resources to maintain the mission system as the Spanish had done. By 1834, the Mexican government secularized the mission system and began the process of converting church property to private property. Mexican citizens who were helpful during the war for independence and new settlers coming to California bought most of this property. Due to the secularization of the missions, the American Indian converts and Spanish Fathers left Carmel Mission and the mission’s buildings faced deterioration and decay.

Many of the mission’s adobe buildings returned to the earth, becoming piles of mud, while the church’s roof collapsed leaving the interior exposed to the elements. By 1859, the United States government, which was now in control of California, returned the missions’ lands to the Catholic Church. Carmel Mission lay in ruin. Restoration of the mission began in 1884 when private funds provided a new roof for the church. By 1936, private funds and church funds became available for a full-scale renovation of the property. Over the next two decades the mission’s buildings were rebuilt and restored, and in 1961, it was designated a Basilica. A Basilica is the highest honorary rank for a church and implies great historical and artistic importance.

Today, visitors to the restored and reconstructed Carmel Mission will see the mission, with its complete quadrangle courtyard. Only part of the mission buildings date from the 18th and 19th centuries while others are of more recent construction but still in the California mission style. Many of the church’s interior furnishings are original. In 1851, Monterey Pastor Father Villarasa removed the church’s statues, paintings, and other artifacts when the church’s roof showed signs of collapse. The Old Presidio Chapel in Monterey then used the furnishings until the early part of the 20th century when they returned to Carmel Mission. Visitors to the mission will also see California’s First Library (founded in 1770) that contains Father Serra’s 400 year-old Bible.

Carmel Mission, a National Historic Landmark, is located at 3080 Rio Rd. in Carmel, CA.

quickFacts.value: One of the most authentically restored Roman Catholic mission churches in California.
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Station 9 Boulders

images.altText: Granite boulders in a field of sage brush.
images.title: Boulders

data.bodyText:
Boulders 

Boulders break from an outcrop when they are weathered to the point of instability or toppled during an earthquake. Earthquakes of low magnitude are not uncommon, but large-scale land shifts or movements have not occurred here in recorded history. A fault near Smoky Mountain Campground is estimated to be as recent as 10,000 years ago. 

Many climbers prefer granite of the Green Creek Complex over that of the Almo pluton because the large potassium feldspar crystals make for great holds. Take note of these crystals as you pass by.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Ice Cave and Bandera Volcano
data.listingDescription: Explore the Bandera Crater and Ice Cave at this privately owned site within El Malpais National Monument. An entrance fee is required to visit this incredible lava landscape.

images.altText: A green and white building sits between large pine trees and assorted decorations.
images.title: Ice Caves Trading Post
images.caption: The Trading Post at the Ice Caves and Bandera Volcano

data.bodyText:
For a real experience in contrast, visit the Ice Cave and Bandera Volcano, "The Land of Fire and Ice," right on the Continental Divide. Walk through the twisted old-growth juniper, fir, and ponderosa pine trees, over the ancient lava trails, into the core of a volcano, and down into a lava tube cave.  Inside the cave, the natural layers of ice glisten blue-green in the reflected rays of sunlight illuminating natural arctic algae. Take a walk around the Bandera Volcano and view one of the best examples of a cinder cone volcanic eruption in the country.

Because Ice Cave and Bandera Volcano are privately owned, a small fee is required for entry. The historic Trading Post offers opportunities for shopping and learning about the history of the area and the family who owns the property.
data.audioDescription: A dirt road brings you to a large turn-around. several building and a small water tower border the parking area. Large pine trees surround the buildings, and in the distance the Bandera volcano rises above the trees.

data.title: Castle Rocks Geological Area Overlook

images.altText: Craggy granite formations jut up in a mountainous landscape glowing in sunrise light.
images.title: Castle Rocks Geologic Area

data.bodyText:
From this rocky ridge, hikers can view the Stines Creek riparian area below and watch for birds and other wildlife; however, it is the Castle Rocks Geologic Area that dominates one’s attention. The towering spires and monoliths of the Almo Pluton fall within areas managed by the State Park, Bureau of Land Management, and Forest Service. 

This topography results from crustal extension. As the crust is stretched, high angle faults develop. Along these faults, mountains uplift and valleys drop, creating the distinctive mountain ranges.

As rocky ranges rise, the newly exposed rock is immediately subjected to weathering and erosion. This rock is attacked by water, ice, wind, and other erosive agents, that have produced many of the geologic features visible today.
data.managedByOrg: Idaho Department of Parks and Recreation

data.title: Geological Trail Intro Part 1

images.altText: Cloudy overview with granite pinnacles jutting out around green meadows in Circle Creek Basin
images.title: Circle Creek Basin

data.bodyText:
Introduction 

City of Rocks National Reserve is part of the Basin and Range geologic province. Basin and Range topography results from crustal extension. As the crust is stretched (pulled apart), high angle faults develop. Along these faults, mountains uplift and valleys drop, creating the distinctive mountain ranges and wide valleys of theBasin and Range province.  

As rocky ranges rise, the newly exposed rock is immediately subjected to weathering and erosion. This rock is attacked by water, ice, wind, and other erosive agents, that have produced many of the geologic features visible today.  

The majority of outcrops at City of Rocks, and all of the pinnacles, consist of intrusive igneous rock with a granitic composition. Geologists have mapped the two different types of granitic rock within the Reserve as the Green Creek Complex and the Almo pluton.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Geological Trail Intro Part 3

images.altText: Close up of Almo Pluton with a ruler for scale, particles are about 2-4 mm.
images.title: Almo Pluton

data.bodyText:
Almo Pluton 

Most of the pinnacles at City of Rocks and Castle Rocks are made of granite from the Almo pluton. The pluton started out as an intrusive body of magma and has a convoluted contact with the Green Creek Complex. It is the youngest rock at City of Rocks and formed about 28 million years ago. 

Unlike the granite of the Green Creek Complex, the Almo pluton has an equigranular texture. Notice in the photograph the small uniform size of the crystals in the Almo pluton in contrast to the variety of sizes in the Green Creek Complex. 

Both types of granite are cut in many places by dikes of pegmatite, a very coarse-grained granitic rock that usually forms during the last stages of crystallization of a large granitic pluton. The pegmatites at City of Rocks contain large quartz and feldspar crystals about the size of a fist.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Station 1 Granitic Weathering

images.altText: Granite formation showing examples of weathering, exfoliation, case hardening, and grus.
images.title: Geological Trail Station 1

data.bodyText:
Granitic Weathering 

Weather is the agent responsible for creating the bizarre and fantastic shapes that characterize the area. Weathering occurs on the surface of outcrops by granular disintegration (one layer of crystals after another are removed from the surface). This weathering leaves the newly exposed surface in a smooth rounded condition with no sharp or ragged edges. The detrital material is carried by wind and water to low areas among the prominent outcrops. The detrital material (granitic sand) that is found at the base of most outcrops is called grus. Weathering-related features seen here include case hardening, exfoliation, and grus (located at the base of the outcrop).
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Station 12 Pinnacles

images.altText: Towering granite pinnacles.
images.title: Pinnacles

data.bodyText:
Pinnacles 

A pinnacle is a large, steep-sided, rock outcrop. The shape of a pinnacle is primarily controlled by weathering of vertical joints. Where the granite contains many joints, pinnacles are smaller, more numerous and more closely spaced, as seen in the photograph below. Weathering of granite with relatively fewer joints results in the larger, more common, isolated pinnacles like Chicken Rock, Lost Arrow Spire, and Creekside Tower. Rare are the pinnacles found in the granite of the Green Creek Complex within the Reserve, but they are numerous along the south slope of Cache Peak in Big Cove.  

As erosion of this multi-jointed wall continues, other pinnacles will begin to form, as noted by the dashed lines below.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.

data.title: Station 2 Panholes

images.altText: Two panholes in a large granite boulder.
images.title: Panholes

data.bodyText:
Panholes 

Panholes begin as tiny depressions or cracks where water remains for long periods of time. The longer water remains on the granite surface, the greater the dissolution of minerals by acidic water. One way that rainwater becomes acidic is when it mixes with decaying vegetation. Another way is when minerals in the rock leach into the water. 

Panholes are sometimes incorrectly called potholes. Actually, a pothole is formed in the rocky bed of a stream by the grinding action of stone(s). There are no known potholes within the Reserve. One of the nearby locations to easily find potholes is in the basaltic bedrock of the Snake River, 50 miles north of here.
data.audioDescription: Dirt trail flanked by sage brush, scattered juniper and pinyon pine trees, in a landscape dotted with granite formations.
