data.title: [Sign] National Treasure Wayside #149

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: National Treasure Wayside. 3 minutes On the edge of the parking area lined with horizontal logs stands this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. A color illustration that assembles, in one scene, many of the plants and animals living in this old-growth forest habitat before you fills the panel. Text on the top left reads: National Treasure. Mingle with the centuries-old giants of Olympic National Park’s old-growth forests and become a part of history. Many of these western hemlock and Douglas-fir trees were thriving before Columbus set sail in 1492. They greeted guests at Sol Duc Resort in 1912 and stood stately when Olympic National Park was established in 1938. From seedlings to 750-year-old sentinels, this multi-layered forest harbors countless residents, from black bears and banana slugs to birds of many songs. In death, old growth takes on vital new roles. Standing snags serve as nesting sites for owls and small mammals. Fallen trees become nurse logs where saplings can sprout above the crowded forest floor. Decomposing leaves and logs provide refuge for salamanders, beetles and a bustling unseen world. This magnificent old-growth forest offers adventure and solace for wilderness enthusiasts from around the globe. It is a finely tuned system that ties the past to the present. Will this national treasure be a link to our future?” The illustration is a ground level view of an old growth forest. On the forest floor, a fallen tree dominates the foreground. It is covered with moss, white wildflowers, and plants with red berries. A snake, with its red tongue extended, slithers up the side of the tree. On top, are two yellow slugs with black spots and antenna, a black and orange bird, and two small pine tree saplings. Attached to the side of the tree are orange and white shelf-like fungi. On the ground, a small brown and white squirrel holds a pinecone. Next to the fallen tree on the left, the head of a small grey animal with dark eyes, short snout, and small rounded ears, peeks out from behind a moss-covered tree stump. In the forest background, a black bear walks by a tall plant with wide green leaves and red flowers. A brown elk with two five-pointed antlers stands near the wide base of tree. A brown and whited spotted owl is perched at the top of a dead tree, while below, a black and white woodpecker with a bright red head, clings to the bark. A small bird sits on its nest on a high moss-covered tree branch as a brown bird flies into the forest. On the left, a group of hikers walk through the forest.

data.title: [Sign] Night Shadows Wayside #147

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Night Shadows Wayside. 2 minutes At this roadside pull off, horizontal logs line the edge of the parking area. In the grass opposite one of the logs, is the three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. A color illustration assembling many of the plants and animals that live in the forest habitat before you, fills the panel. Text on the left reads: Night Shadows. Enter Olympic’s old-growth forest at twilight and share the darkening hours. A Columbia black-tailed deer unveils her silhouette through the evening curtain. Elusive cougars stalk deer by scent and sound. Songs of owls and frogs quicken the air. Fiery shadows leap from tree to tree as the setting sun kindles an intricate night world. One night creature, the northern spotted owl, needs old growth for survival. This threatened species nests in broken treetops and trunk hollows far above the forest floor. Flying squirrels, favored prey of spotted owls, scurry down to the forest floor to dig for truffles and spread the spores of future fungi. At this moment of opportunity, a vigilant spotted owl swoops down to snag a squirrel. Northern spotted owls, flying squirrels and truffles weave a unique tapestry in the old-growth forest night. What other vital connections can you discover? The illustration is a ground level view of a forest of tall trees, its floor covered in a lush carpet of green ferns, moss and decaying wood. Above the ground is an owl in flight with outstretched, upward curved brown wings edged with individual finger-like feathers and fanned out tail feathers. It has a white and brown chest and round head with two large dark round eyes and a thin white downward curved beak. A thin line of dark feathers shaped like a heart encircles its face. Clawed feet hang from its legs. On the ground, a grayish-brown squirrel crouches near a fallen tree, and a brown deer with large ears stands sideways as a brown cougar walks nearby.

data.title: [Sign] North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside #164c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Wild Coast Wayside. 1 minute Be advised. Driftwood may be scattered on the beach blocking clear access to the wayside. On this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel, text in the bottom right corner reads: Wild Coast. The sea makes the rules. Hiking this long stretch of wilderness beach, you may have to climb headlands, cross numerous streams, enter a cocoon of fog, or follow animal tracks in the sand. There are no sheltered lagoons. If you ignore the tides, storm waves may trap you against a sheer cliff. Find solitude, or a whale’s jawbone, or a kind of bird you’ve never seen before. Filling the top half of the panel is a blue and white drawing of a wave hitting the rocky shoreline below high tree topped hills. A sea stack is offshore. In the bottom left corner, a blue and white drawing shows a hiker holding a hiking pole while traversing a jumble of rocks at the base of a hill, the ocean in the background. DONE – EG ..................Column Break..................Site Number: 164c – North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside 152 words North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside. 1 minute A map of the North Wilderness Coast Hike fills this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel. The land is brown, and the ocean is blue. Ozette Lake also in blue is inland. The trail hugs the coast from Rialto Beach in the south to Cape Alava in the north. The text, You Are Here, marks your current location at Rialto Beach. In between the beginning and end of the trail, are marked locations for Hole-in-the-Wall, Cape Johnson, Norwegian Memorial, Yellow Banks, and Sand Point. Inland trails are marked by dashed lines at Sand Point and Cape Alava. The Ozette Ranger Station at the northern tip of Ozette Lake is marked with a Ranger and tent logo. Text reads: Caution: If no headland trail exists, wait until low tide before rounding Point. Leashed pets allowed only from Rialto Beach to Ellen Creek. Backcountry permits required for overnight camping.

data.title: [Sign] Protect Salmon Wayside #139

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Protect Salmon Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of the path leading to the amphitheater stands this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Filling the panel is a color illustration showing a cutaway view of a creek with salmon. Text reads: Protect Salmon. Please Don’t build dams or disturb the creek. Any disturbance to the gravel in this creek can be fatal to salmon. Coho salmon assume many different forms throughout their life. In the fall, adult salmon return from the ocean to spawn and deposit their eggs in the gravel. The young emerge in the spring and eventually swim back to the ocean beginning the cycle again. In the illustration, red salmon eggs deposited on the gravelly creek bottom are hatching. Several young orange-red salmon with yolk sacs attached to their bodies swim above the gravel in the blue green water. Other small salmon swim nearby, their egg sacs gone, and in the background, two adult salmon with spotted backs and red sides swim side-by-side.
